summary: It's been 40 years since Laurie Strode survived a vicious attack from crazed killer Michael Myers on Halloween night. Locked up in an institution, Myers manages to escape when his bus transfer goes horribly wrong. Laurie now faces a terrifying showdown when the masked madman returns to Haddonfield, Ill. -- but this time, she's ready for him.

reviews.content: a prequel to The original Halloween it is decent and passes the time Michael Myers comes back to finish what he started
Terrifying. Edge of your seat. Brutal in the most visceral way, almost hysterical even but so damn engaging. I do wish the third act was more dramatic but it did it’s job.

While this movie didn't necessarily have to be made, I'm somewhat glad that they did for the entertainment value (just like Halloween 2). I was mostly satisfied as a horror movie fan and some of the directing and storytelling techniques worked quite well (while some others didn't which I will get to later). I liked Jaime Lee Curtis in her role and Michael Myers was scary/menacing/terrifying as always and it was good that they never showed his face. The fact that they included the original music with variations of it and put it in appropriate scenes/used it well was noteworthy. I very much liked that they killed off the investigating/research characters early in the movie and didn't leave them around since they would've probably ended up being a nuisance and annoying like those kinds of characters are in other horror movies. It was clever how they referenced the other old movies about half of the time and had Laurie switch places with Michael in a few ways, however the other half of the callbacks made me roll my eyes. Plus the horny teenagers bothered me again, that was probably the worst thing about the original even though it was good, but it's frustrating that they didn't learn that lesson and kept that trope in. I guess another bad thing about this movie is that it inspired even more sequels after this which it shouldn't have and doesn't make sense since Michael should've gotten incinerated into ash at the end. I would've liked it if it ended after this one similar to how the original second one should have ended it back in the 80s. Hollywood and the studios will never ever put practical and logical thinking before the money that making more sequels can give them though, smh.

This is a great sequel and in my opinion is as good as the original. The acting and writing is gritty and realistic and there are some great funny moments in there as well. This is such a solid film. The original is a trailblazing masterpiece but in terms of entertainment value and production quality, this matches it.
Halloween 2018 is easily nowhere near the original but is a good follow up to the original.

While I know this is an unpopular opinion, I actually like 2018 more than the original, for many reasons. While I still love the original movie, this just has a bigger budget to do more brutal kills and more kills overall. They bring back the legacy characters without using Nostalgia as a tool for audiences. The story is simply more enthralling than the original and Michael is in the movie more than the original. This is a fun slasher and a must-watch for any horror fan. Plus, it is way scarier than the original. If you're a horror fan, this is a must-see

David Gordon Green breaths new life into a bottom of the barrel franchise, yes the dialogue and the humor is a little sketchy but I praise the back to basics slasher with some nice homages to past sequels, felt Michael (The Shape) Myers was back to his menacing self with great kills and set prices, great cinematography and a bonus bringing John Carpenter back to help with the score

Michael Myers is back and this times he's senile?
It was a good movie but not as good as some critics claim. And definitely not a masterpiece. There was some plot holes and a lot of loose threads in the story and characters that seems important but then just disappeared. Anybody who hoped it would have reinvented the genre will most likely be disappointed because it really is the same predictable thing we have seen over and over again since the 70's. You soon realize how the whole movie will go.
While the movie has a lot of trivia from the first movie it sometimes doesn't even feel like the people who made it had seen the original. Because for a movie that was all about getting Halloween back to its roots and be like the original it really got a lot of things wrong, something I think has to do with the fact that this movie was based on their head canon of what was happening in the original.
First of all, Michael Myers seems to have forgotten how to be Michael Myers. He no longer stalks his victims before striking, he just goes from house to house killing people like it's a chore, going through the motion. It almost becomes silly and never scary or that interesting to see him just walk around killing people. Luckily they skip most of those killings.
Michael Myers suddenly has super strength. Sure, he was always stronger than a normal person but not like this. I'm talking Jason strong. I saw a question on Quora on how he became super strong and now I get why someone asked that question.
And Laurie Strode apparently has also become super strong because she's stronger than Michael during their battle. And she's not that clever when searching for him, opening doors with her gun so he could have grabbed it.
Michael Myers and Laurie Strode are no longer related and there's no point to it. There is nothing in the movie that makes it impossible for them to be siblings. In fact you wouldn't even have known it if a character hadn't said that someone just made that up to find a reason (that someone was John Carpenter and Debra hill btw). A lot of people are upset by this and that they skipped Halloween 2 (again, for no reason).
You might remember that the people who made this movie said they took away the sibling thing because they felt it made it less scary if Michael Myers had a goal of hunting down Laurie Strode and her family, and some speculated that maybe Laurie would be hunting him instead.
The thing is, in this movie he's STILL hunting for Laurie Strode and her family, and it is still his goal to kill her. In fact the movie goes so far as to say it's his final goal. That they are two opposites that is connected and drawn to each other that can't die until the other one is dead (yes, they even hinted that Laurie Strode too had some kind of power to survive death). This despite them saying they wanted to take away the supernatural feeling of the series and Make Michael Myers just a killer that could be killed.
Wiping the slate clean, Michael Myers is scary as ever in this new reboot, perfect suspense, and love that they included original pieces in this new movie.
Michael was great! Laurie was too! Kills were so bloody. Gore was nice.

Finally after so many average to bad Halloween sequels, Halloween (2018) is an amazing movie, its script is well written and the story is well developed and you are interested in what is being told, the soundtrack is phenomenal it is spectacularly wonderful and tense and really scary at times, and Michael Myers' characterization surpasses that of the 1978 film, finally a sequel that understands the masked killer. David Gordon Green's direction is wonderful it's absurdly amazing and the death scenes are one better than the other, overall it's the best halloween sequel and the decision to give a direct sequel to the 1978 movie was spectacularly well made.
See you later!
Top 3 Halloween movie in the whole entire series.

I don't know why, but I just feel that Michael Myers was actually much more funnier in Austin Powers than in this movie!
So they decided to make a Halloween movie that is a sequel to the original movie, as is if they said screw the all the sequels, but then I personally feel like it didn't actually ruin the all the sequels, they are still very watchable and you could still watch this one after. 

This is a very good sequel to the original, the acting was really good until the ending, the actors really shines when it came to been scared. The story was really good and felt solid, alough it felt like it was just a really long build up to the melodramatic ending of Michael Myers. The score and cinematography was really cinematic, especially hearing the classic Halloween theme and the way the scenes was shot, it was absolutely brilliant. I want to give this movie a higher rating but I have an unpopular opinion, I feel like the the two halves didn't have the same feel, either it's about Laurie fully hunting Michael or it's about Michael going on a full killing spree and it's about one survivor who stops him, both story line was very noticeably different. Like I said just a very unpopular opinion. So for it's cinematography, sound and story, my rating is very reasonable.

Halloween 2018 sees a return to form with a fresh clean slate after years of mind numbingly bad sequels.  The return of Jamie Lee Curtis as one of horrors best finals girls, Laurie Strode, is a very welcome premise, which allows the film to focus primarily on fan service rather than stretch audience patience with a nonsensical plot.  2018 also gives us the best Michael Myers in the entire franchise, nailing the demeanor and movement, while also not holding back on the brutality.  This new Halloween proves that with enough people that care, a slasher can rise again rather easily.

The 11th, that's right, 11th instalment in the Halloween franchise which, like every other horror films series, didn't need to go beyond a single entry, but money talks, and is extremely persuasive, and so 40 years after John Carpenter's game-changing original, we get Halloween. The fact that is shares the same name with the movie that kicked off the series is one of many issues I have with it, but it's by no means the most egregious. The film might be slickly made and well-acted, but like so many other follow ups it struggles to justify its own reason for existing. It's set 40 years after Laurie Strode's misadventure in babysitting, with Strode having gone the Sarah Connor route of becoming a battle-hardened survivalist. Unfortunately, much like Sally Hardesty in the woeful 2022 Texas Chainsaw Massacre film, they've done her dirty. Strode, much like everyone in this movie, is a thundering idiot. I can't stand films where plot points depens on characters being so monumentally stupid. It's the laziest writers crutch I can thing of, right up there with characters not asking basic questions or giving simple explanations. There's a psychiatrist character, presumably a tribute to Dr. Loomis, who exists solely to give Michael a chance to escape and, naturally, be really bloody stupid about it. Myers, despite being a giant lumbering creature of advancing age, is able to sneak around unnoticed wherever he goes, and his imperviousness to bullets and knifes wounds is pushed to the extreme. I was already aware that sequels existed, so Myers surviving wasn't a surprise, but it's so frustrating to see characters we're supposed to like and root for make so many dumb decisions. Strode turning into a Bond villain final in the final few scenes is especially annoying. She doesn't take simple measures to ensure Michael is dead, and then walks away assuming that her plan of burning down her house will do the trick. Predictably, it doesn't, and as a result, this retcon sequel is now a trilogy. Wonderful.

This is my favorite entry in the Halloween franchise, even more than the original 1978 film (although not by much) and a perfect continuation of Michael and Laurie's story in terms of where they would be 40 years later. With a surprisingly slow first half that sets up Michael's return, the second half is where it hits the fan and everything comes together. The cinematography is also very impressive, including a nearly 3 minute one sot and a death scene involving motion sensor lights. The big problem I have with the film are the new characters that sometimes bring the story to a halt and don't serve much of a purpose other than to be killed.  If you enjoy Halloween (1978), I would definitely recommend giving this a try!

Halloween (2018) is a great new start to the franchise. They're able to keep it simple, and go back to their roots, and luckily, it really works. Laurie Strode is written very well, and the introduction of new characters were also well executed. Though, they weren't as interesting. The kills are bloody and plentiful. This very much feels like a popcorn movie; you grab a snack and turn off your brain for an hour and a half. There's no over arching theme, or really anything to think about, the movie actually has little real substance. However, that's how it should be. Also, the plot gets really crazy in the second half. Not necessarily a flaw, but definitely something to note. I feel the movie could have done without this twist, there were better ways to accomplish what the writers wanted. If you go to a Halloween movie expecting a good time and nothing else, you'll be plenty happy.

They really missed the mark with what made Michael scary. It wasn't his high body count, it was how he silently stalked his victims before he killed them by striking at unexpected times. They made him more like Jason Voorhees and it really took me out of the movie.

Lame Sarah Connor imitation. Having loved and worshipped the original Halloween then rewatching it 40 years later with an avid following of fans at the cinema I realised the many faults the film has. The excellent concept, filming and music are let down by goofy moments and outdated pacing. It's still iconic but flawed. The new Halloween is nothing but flawed. I feel like I'm watching a really dated film that is trying to be ironic but comes across sarcastic and tiresome. The scares are lacking, the characters unconvincing, the development dull and so on. I could not be more disappointed. Halloween: H20 (1998) was better, at least it got the Halloween vibe and was entertaining. The only decent recent remake was It (2017), that was phenomenal and I didn't get my phone out once watching that. The music and filming are the only positives of the new Halloween. Maybe it'll go full circle and I might enjoy it in 40 years.

A long awaited sequel that was a big relief for the years of lackluster sequels and remakes. Halloween 2018 does a great job bringing back Jamie Lee Curtis and fitting her into the new story and James Jude Courtney's portrayal of Michael is arguably one of the best.

I loved this movie. Halloween fans have waited a long time for a really good film like this and now we've finally got it.
The casting was excellent, it was strange not having Loomis in pursuit of Michael but his replacement Dr Sartain I thought was really good! Although he was absolutely insane.
Enjoyed the story and there were some great kills too.

Would highly recommend

Halloween (2018)  and the sequel, Halloween Kills (2021) Are the Halloween movies that we've needed for a long time. David Gordon Green keeps both movies true too the 1978 Halloween film that John Carpenter wrote and Directed, along with Debrah Hill at the time. The camera angles and the style of this film is perfect. They brought back the classic look of Michael Myers and the original cinematography that looks extremely close too the original Halloween movie, and John Carpenter is probably very proud. He is able too bash Rob Zombie and tell him, look this is how do a Halloween movie, the way you did it, was totally bad, in Halloween II (2009). The performances are amazing and the special effects are great. This is Halloween movie and Halloween Kills are both the best Halloween movies since both Halloween (1978) and Halloween II (1981) combined into one big movie, Which was amazing as well. I hope David Gordon Green does more horror movies and picks an amazing filmmaker too continue the Halloween franchise after Halloween Ends premieres. The movie script came together well, and it went from page too screen very well. All of the props were great as well. The knife that Michael Myers (Jude Courtney/Nick Castle) uses, looks amazing and very realistic when a real knife is not used. The camera operators did a fantastic job knowing how too do close ups, and at what angles they should be shooting from. David Gordon Green did a great job on both directing and writing the movie. The producers did a great job of budgeting the film as well. Everything came perfectly together, as all movies should come together. Flawless in every way.
it would have been a lot more entertaining if I didn't have to watch that old hag Jamie Lee Curtis
This Halloween movie is really great. What I like with this is that it isn't one of these slasher movies. It's more thrilling than disgusting and I really recommend this one.

It's thrilling to see a new Halloween sequel in time for the 40th anniversary of the first movie which came out in 1978.   This new installment is one of the best in the franchise, which had several sequels throughout the past decades. What's great about this one is how they went back to basics and delivered raw scares and dread. They didn't hold back on blood and gore either. Jamie Lee Curtis reprising her role as the main protagonist is also one of the highlights of the movie. It reminded me of other badass female leads like Sarah Connor from Terminator. I like the psychological tones in the movie. I also like how they made the first half brutal, and the second half very suspenseful. I am glad that Michael Myers is back in business and his name is being re-introduced for the new generation. Hoping that this will not be the final installment.

Halloween (2018) takes the best qualities of Halloween (1978) and adds all the technical progress from 40 years of horror-slasher films.  

Jamie Lee Curtis reprises her role as Laurie Strode and gives the audience a tour de force performance.  However, this time around, Jamie is surrounded by a cast of exceptional actors.

This movie manages to be a great homage to classic slashers and deliver a refreshing experience.  Michael Myers has never been scarier.  He is ruthless and unstoppable.  

The plot of Halloween (2018) shares the spotlight with many members of the terrorized community.  The script shines in how it focuses on the intergenerational trauma of Laurie Strode, her daughter, and granddaughter.  Their relationships are strained and humanized.  Where many slasher films have been explorative to their female cast, this film is empowering.

There are a few detractions that keep this from reaching a higher rating.  Some characters designed to serve the plot are caricature rather than realistic.  There are a few pretty hokey scenes.  There are few times where the audience feels scared; we are mostly left to feel worried for characters we like (or enjoy the very well-done carnage).

It's clear that David Green has tremendous love for Rick Rosenthal's Halloween II (1981). Sometimes it seems Halloween (2018) pays more homage to that film than Carpenter's 1978 original. The only difference now in Halloween (2018) is Laurie Strode (Jamie Lee Curtis) and The Shape (Nick Castle) are no longer siblings, which apparently was always Carpenter's true intention before Halloween II revealed otherwise. Even still Green doesn't offer anything new to the Halloween mythos because everything has already been done numerous times prior. Green even takes a cue from Steve Miner's Halloween H20: Twenty Years Later and retcons the bad sequels. Likewise, Jamie Lee Curtis reprises her role as Laurie Strode and [again] the premise is largely the same as that in H20. The one exception is that Green shows that The Shape can be contained. We learn The Shape was captured at the end of Carpenter's film and has been incarcerated for the last forty years. This alteration to the original's end is actually a bit more grounded with reality. As opposed to H20, which had The Shape lingering about for twenty years as an urban legend. Green does incorporate the gritty tone established in Rob Zombie's Halloween adaptions but merges this into Carpenter's canon. John Carpenter returning to score and produce definitely brings the franchise back to its roots. This shift of focus is now back to The Shape leaving Laurie Strode's perspective secondary. I'm not sure if it was even necessary for Green to span this film into a trilogy. He could've just wrapped everything up in this film leaving its ending as an homage to Halloween II's. While albeit cliche, spawning The Shape back into the flames of hell is generally a symbolic way of conquering evil. Still, post-1978, The Shape is as brutal as ever but barely as scary.

A great revival of a classic. Jamie Lee Curtis is fantastic as a reimagined almost Ripply-esque Laurie, and centering the film around the multigenerational trauma of her past is both brilliant and immediately engaging. There is depth to this horror installment even if the plot follows largely along avenues well trodden before. Solid acting performances all around, good jump scares, and enough unsettling enough to be scary without having to be needlessly cruel or overly graphic. Fun, fresh, and energetic

Halloween is a wonky film, yet creates for a good time with some solid scares. Director David Gordon Green is rooted in the film's vision, yet he does not produce the best suspense in the horror flick. Only two out of the several killing scenes truly have an anxiety-filling tone that can bring the scare level to its most distinguished point. Green also makes it too apparent where Michael is hiding before killing a victim. What was so excellent about the original film was that it had those moments that you never knew what was coming. These kills feel predictable and somewhat redundant at times. However, there are some chilling moments in the film. There is a scene in the movie where a character places the iconic mask on themselves. Green got the sequence correct by making it felt like a terrifying, contemporary twist on the Halloween franchise. The writing also feels like a mixed bag at some points in Halloween. The first act is surprisingly weak and does not set up this film in a perfect way. The podcast angle of the film did not work and took away from the heart of the horror flick. There should be suspense and thrill in the opening, not two podcasters lurking throughout the life of Michael. There were plenty of different ways Michael could have got out of the psychiatric hospital and how he obtained the mask. This storyline was not the way to go with it. However, the second and the third acts are solid, with chilling thrills and stellar character arcs. Most of Laurie's actions feel justified, and her relationship with her daughter, Karen, is a core aspect of the film. It is a relief that the film ends strong because the first 30 minutes of Halloween are rough. As for the technical components in Halloween, they are all solid. The editing is the most limited out of them all and brings down the film just imperceptibly. There are a few scenes where the editing is a little choppy and do not flow well into the next scene. However, those long takes were cut at the perfect time, as they are never too drawn out but never extremely short. The cinematography in this film is exquisite. As discussed a few phrases ago, the long shots were well done and created an influential curiosity about what might happen next. The score is exceptional as it uses John Carpenter's themes very nicely, but the composers slightly expand on it to make it distinctive to this movie. The cast of Halloween is strong, yet there were some slight bumps in the ensemble. Jamie Lee Curtis is phenomenal in the role of Laurie Strode. Curtis matures the character to feel very powerful and influential in this installment of the franchise, leaving a substantial impact on the film. Judy Greer is great as Karen and plays the estranged daughter role very well. Andi Matichak is a shining star as Allyson. Matichak felt like a modern Laurie Strode yet still made Allyson unique to her. Matichak had some great scenes and had fabulous chemistry with everyone in the cast. Will Patton is the weakest out of everyone as his line delivery is awful. Patton makes Deputy Frank Hawkins look like he can not do his job and delivers all his lines like a catchphrase. It is hard to watch Patton perform in this film. Lastly, there is Haluk Bilginer, who takes control of every scene where he is present. The turbulent temperament Bilginer gives Dr. Ranbir Sartain is just chilling to watch. Halloween is a solid movie yet is brought down by a few weak story elements and half-baked directing. While the script and direction are not to the most crucial degrees, the cast and technical components of the film are almost perfect. Halloween was close to becoming a supreme horror reboot, yet it does not fulfill the proper criteria to achieve that status. Read more reviews like this at postcreditreviews.com

Despite maintaining the same name, Halloween (2018) is a direct follow up to Halloween (1978), wisely ignoring all of the sequels, giving us a simple and reasonable continuation of that film. It is instantly clear from the start that this sequel intends to stand strong by the originals side as it contains some beautiful cinematography, smartly captured long takes and the return of John Carpenter providing a truly outstanding score, modernising his classic theme, making Halloween (2018) feel like a special horror film attempt rather than an easy cash grab.

The return of Jamie Lee Curtis proves to be very captivating as there is so much history between her and Michael Meyers, which you are constantly reminded of thanks to recreations of iconic shots.

What holds sequel back from matching the quality of the original is a few plot issues, the main one involving Dr. Sartain, which just feels unbelievable and silly. Besides that, Halloween (2018) is a film which fans of the franchise can appreciate for being the best one since the original, it is both beautifully shot as well as containing one of the best horror scores of all time, instantly providing goosebumps.

In my opinion, this sequel is actually better than the original. Set 40 years after the original, it does a great job of showing the consequences of the original on not only Laurie but on her loved ones in the years that followed too. A much different sequel than the 1982 one, but definitely an effective and well-told one.
Very impressive sequel, did everything correct. Was brutal, gory and deliciously scary. definitely see this one

Halloween is the sequel to the original film of the same name from 1978 directed by iconic horror director John Carpenter. This one is a direct sequel ignoring the previous ones which were not well received directed by David Gordon Green of Pineapple Express. The movie is fun and greatly honors the legacy of the original by using the same title and even the same intro. That can be quite on the nose but the story is compelling bringing back Myers after several decades in confinement, he escapes and wreaks havoc on Haddonfield again. By bringing back Jamie Lee Curtis Laurie main character from the original, the movie gives it an emotional core and gives the movie purpose as Curtis character becomes a PTSD tortured old lady who's badass with guns and survival skills bent on killing Myers. Green directs this movie beautifully with beautiful cinematography and great jump scares and very terrifying moments. The script is riddled with some bad dialogue and some cheesy elements but is coupled with Myers being meaner and more violent than the original. The ending is electrifying and with Curtis back this one is a great sequel to one of the great horror films of American pop culture.
Expands upon the original film like none of the other sequels did. Halloween (2018) is compelling and intense from start to finish and features a legendary performance from Jamie Lee Curtis.

After finally getting rid of the brother / sister narrative between Myers and Laurie, Halloween (2018) is a direct sequel to the original 1978 movie of the same name directed by John Carpenter. This movie instead focuses on a timeline 40 years in the future from the 1978 movie, where Laurie has been preparing for Michael to escape confinement by training herself and her family in combat, and trapping out her entire house. This movie is a great sequel to the original, although I might enjoy the original Halloween II just a little bit more. I think this timeline has more potential than where the original went. The acting performances are great throughout and without the forgettable and kind of stupid doctor that seemed to replace the unreplacable in Loomis, this film has more memorable characters than most in the franchise do. The ending bothers me a little bit but it leaves room for the next movie in the franchise to begin, albeit not in my favorite spot. This movie is very enjoyable and the call backs to the past movies were especially amazing, definitely a great start to this new timeline.

Halloween - 8/10. David Gordon Green's reboot/reimagining sequel to original Halloween was one of the better horror films of the last decade. With a Sarah Connor like Jamie Lee Curtis in the lead, the series takes an interesting turn toward a more grittier and grizzly violent turn with this instalment. Green brings back Michael Myers as a Terminator like force. Myers is ruthless and seems even more stronger than the other instalments. The scene in the washroom alone shows the film's ruthless path its going down for the future of the franchise. Its interesting where Green is directing the series towards to, almost making the conflict between the main characters almost like a war. With the future sequels, it looks like we mights see some backstory involved, but what I liked most about this film is that there's no flashbacks or anything. Everything is moving forward, and I like the surprising action element being brought out in the film's climax. Lets see where the future has in store for this franchise!

7.75/10. H20 was a perfectly acceptable send off to horror legend Michael Myers until money-grubbing and cash-grabbing drag him back from the grave and into two decades of unimaginative, and even ridiculous, sequels. This title disposes of generations of superfluousness and silliness, conferring upon itself true sequel-hood to the 1978 original. It largely earns that self-anointment, with a reliably strong performance from Jamie Lee Curtis as a terminally broken and paranoid Laurie Strode that anchors a movie filled with worthy supporting performances and modern, economic film making from director David Gordon Green. Myers is terrifying once more as he pursues a cast of reasonably three-dimensional characters. Brief breathes of humor help this flick from sinking too far into the mucky territory of it's predecessors, but credit must also go to a screen play that feels plausible and worthy of the original. I worry that the two forthcoming sequels will plunge this series back into putrid, creatively devoid mediocrity, but you have to appreciate these good sequels when you get them.

Mediocre at best. Annoying at worst. The film messes up even the basics of what Michael Myers is, and that is not a psychopath, but something evil, something unstoppable, with no emotion and reason that only he understands. He doesn't try to scare people before he kills them for no reason. He's not Jeepers Creepers. And he doesn't go out of his way to kill people that have nothing to do with his target or the path to her just because they had sex. He's also not Jason Voorhees. He only kills those who get in his way, try to stop him or happen to be in the wrong place when he comes through looking for his sister. No one really knew why he wanted to kill her or why he started killing in the first place. He wasn't a psychopath. He wasn't even Michael any more. He was something purely evil, with only one purpose, wipe out his family line. This is not a proper continuation of that story, no matter how much you ignore. Starting from where you expect us to start, it doesn't fit. There was nothing special about the mask either. He grabbed it off a random store rack. He didn't have any kind of connection with it. Yeah, he's not Leatherface either. He's Michael Myers. Really, do it right or don't do it at all.

I'm sorry but half the deaths that occur in this film occur in a way that the original Michael Myers would have done. "The night he came home" Even after 40 years on, John Carpenter's horror classic remains an endearing part of Horror cinema. Not only paving for the way the genre was to change in years to come but just how marketable and financially successful a film with a minimal budget and fewer resources could be. The film, in the early stages, was going to be called The Babysitter Murders but the title Halloween is what stuck.

The story goes that a young boy named Michael Myers commits the ultimate evil by murdering his older sister with a big kitchen knife. As a result, he is put into the care of Doctor Loomis played by Donald Pleasence. Michael Myers subsequently escapes the confines of the asylum and flees to his hometown of Haddonfield on Halloween night. While in Haddonfield, local babysitter Laurie Strode played by then-unknown Jamie Lee Curtis, has to fight to survive Michael's killing spree before the night ends.

Earning early-on negative reception by the critics, the film overtime became revised as a brilliant piece of film-making and influence on directors and audiences to this day. As a result of the film's box office success - several sequels were spawned - to capitalise on the ‘slasher' craze that emerged during the 1980s. Most of these did not earn the respect of the critics or vast majority of fans of the original.

Halloween 2018 is the third attempt to bring out the series from the doldrums and to also bring back Laurie Strode into the core of the story once again. Starting with Halloween H2O in 1998, followed by Rob Zombie's 2007 remake of John Carpenter's original. Neither of which ended up being warmly embraced by audiences and critics. The story here re-writes everything the sequels created and carries on precisely 40 years since the original film's timeline. Laurie Strode once again played by Jamie Lee Curtis, has become a paranoid mess since the events of the first film. Having been estranged from her daughter played by Judy Greer for whom she has fought to protect and train for what may come; along with her granddaughter.

Michael Myers has since been captured and held prisoner at Smith's Grove Sanitarium where two journalists arrive and confront him with his trademark mask. After a prison transfer involving Michael goes wrong, it enables him to escape once more and go back to the town that made him a legend. After being left in doubt her for many years, Laurie soon gets word on his escape and is ready to arm herself. She will have to prep her family - for what she has been preparing them for - throughout their whole lives: the return of Michael Myers.

This particular sequel to the original is undoubtedly an affectionate one. Director David Gordon Green (Undertow, Stronger) and writer Danny McBride have expertly carved an entry that attempts to evoke the original film's style and pace. The opening credit sequences and theme alone are made the same. The film contains nods to the original that are shown in certain scenes which evoke a feeling of homage but in the right way. Jamie Lee Curtis is fantastic in reprising her role, exuding a broken down but equally strong persona. Left scarred after her last encounter with Michael, she is clearly having a ball portraying Laurie Strode as essentially a ‘Sarah Conner' figure in contrast.

Judy Greer is also excellent, though not always given enough to do. As her screen time is often sidelined for Laurie's granddaughter and her high-school friends. All of whom are ready to party and have a good time as the genre often features in these stories. David Gordon Green also knows how to light and direct Michael Myers as the haunting boogeyman in the most appropriate way. With scenes where Michael appears in shadow, or where Michael appears in jump scares involving a cupboard, evoking a sense of dread and foreboding. Nick Castle reprises his role as Michael Myers and clearly has lost none of that movement and menace that made the character famous formerly.

There are elements where the film falters. Such as, much of the film places bigger emphasise on teenage characters as a way that seems very marketable but takes away more important plot strands. Most importantly, the relationship between Laurie Strode and her daughter, which could have been explored more in-depth. Some of the pastiche elements of the film work for me. However, others may feel that it's merely retreading ground; reminding of them of something better that came before this. There is also one plot device near the third act involving a central character. That when it was revealed, felt very mind-boggling and almost took me out of the film entirely.

Overall Halloween 2018 is undoubtedly a cut above the past sequels, which probably wasn't that hard seeing as one entry involved Michael Myers facing off against Busta Rhymes (really!). The acting here is excellent, particularly from Jamie Lee Curtis. The atmosphere evokes dread and suspense, there is a good use of gore presented here and works as a decent follow up to John Carpenter's bogeyman-fearing masterpiece.

Not great, but not bad. Enjoyable overall. I never did watch the original Halloween movies, but I feel I got what I was expecting. It was entertaining enough for me to want to watch the next movie in the series. Hopefully it will be a bit better.

Halloween is one of the cleverly written franchise horror movie to date. Aside from giving us moviegoers the nostalgia of original Halloween of 1978, it sets a retroactive continuity of the franchise as it directly continues as the sequel of the first Halloween film in which the events take place exactly 40 years since the first. I say the writers was so clever in writing this sequel because the story of Halloween this time has more depth, more substance and more characterization. Plus, the whole plot made sense and purpose of what the first film has already established. I also love that this Halloween film goes back again to the elements that made first film a notable horror slasher film. It incorporated a lot of themes and elements up the iconic musical score of the first film that made it a classic horror film.
And what a better to do this sequel than to made the iconic Halloween star and scream queen Jamie Lee Curtis to return again as Laurie Strode, 40 years later! But this time Curtis played Laurie as a mature woman with tougher, smarter and braver qualities that she learned from the events 40 years ago. Curtis is still impressive and loved how she played Laurie this time with more substance and personality. With this sequel, we sorely miss Donald Pleasence as Dr. Sam Loomis which I think this film would be awesome if he returns as I think his character would be pivotal in this current sequel.  Good thing, his absence was compensated by great supporting cast like Judy Greer, Will Patton and newcomer Andi Matichak. Halloween is not just a fan service movie but its return to its roots and origins made it the same effective horror slasher film that it is known for! But this time with fresh suspense, thrill and mystery to its bag, Halloween ranks as the best sequel to date of the franchise.

I can respect the fact that people actually tried to make a good horror movie. You can tell unlike a bunch of other horror movies around the time, they were actually trying to be scary. It has quite a few moments, one scene that really stands out was when Mike Myers was in the neighborhood and got his knife and killed some people, and the fact that it was all in one take, that scene was actually really good. The cinematography was pretty good, the pacing was decent, and the soundtrack was pretty great. But the biggest problem I have, the problem I have with all these damn horror remakes, is that you are never going to make a movie as good as the first Halloween. For a soft reboot of the series, I’m kinda disappointed. There’s a lot of I’ve been there, I’ve seen that before, and I know who Mike Myers is, and the fact that he isn’t scary anymore. Everything feels uninspired, and it falls flat on its face at quite a few times, and with the moments it does have, it also has a lot of dumb sh*t. Full of annoying characters, weak scares, and a weak script. I could tell the actors we’re trying, in particular, I thought Jamie Lee Curtis was trying way to hard at times, but I don’t think they saved the movie. Even though it took itself more serious that the other sequels, there is not a bone in this films body that is remotely scary. And you compare this to the original Halloween, and every aspect is on point, and John Carpenter’s style bring the movie up so much, by building that sense of eeriness and claustrophobia, and the fact that you feel Mike Myers is always watching, works so well for the movie. And those aspects were kinda absent and lacking from this movie, cause I just wasn’t scared. I mean it was ok, I can tell everyone cared, it’s certainly better than the other sequels in the series, but it’s just a shame it’s not as good as I thought it would be. Not scary, didn’t work that well, tried too hard at points, but overall I enjoyed parts of it.

Gender roles not only in the original, but in classic horror films as a whole, are masterfully addressed and responded to. Subtle comparisons drawn between Myers and Laurie Strode work with the soundtrack, lighting and cinematography that takes its time and echoes techniques used in the original, to give a sense of the same story, being told through the same lens, yet told in the present, also demonstrating the effect of the past on Laurie's and her family's present, in this fictional world. References to the original do not feel trite or forced, instead these are twisted to suit the new era while subtly reminding you of the atmosphere of, and why you loved, the original.

7.75/10. H20 was a perfectly acceptable send off to horror legend Michael Myers until money-grubbing and cash-grabbing drag him back from the grave and into two decades of unimaginative, and even ridiculous, sequels. This title disposes of generations of superfluousness and silliness, conferring upon itself true sequel-hood to the 1978 original. It largely earns that self-anointment, with a reliably strong performance from Jamie Lee Curtis as a terminally broken and paranoid Laurie Strode that anchors a movie filled with worthy supporting performances and modern, economic film making from director David Gordon Green. Myers is terrifying once more as he pursues a cast of reasonably three-dimensional characters. Brief breathes of humor help this flick from sinking too far into the mucky territory of it's predecessors, but credit must also go to a screen play that feels plausible and worthy of the original. I worry that the two forthcoming sequels will plunge this series back into putrid, creatively devoid mediocrity, but you have to appreciate these good sequels when you get them.

Halloween starts off strong with one of the best cold opens I have ever seen. From there we are introduced to the intriguing premise that is a returning Jamie Lee Curtis playing a hardened Laurie Strode who has been waiting her whole life for Michael Myers to escape so she can kill him. Perhaps the best part of this film is Curtis' performance playing a very different Laurie Strode than we saw in the original 1978 Halloween. The filmmakers choose to disregard every Halloween sequel which plays to their benefit because, as an audience, we get to see a fresh take on John Carpenter's slasher classic. Halloween is a nice balance of fresh and new; there are plenty of call backs to the original to give fans a heavy dose of nostalgia but they also find new and creative ways to build tension. One gripe I have with this film is that, at times, it falls under the weight of familiar tropes and cliches and unfortunately the occasional cheap jump-scare. However, the negatives are significantly outweighed by the positives and I can say with complete confidence that Halloween 2018 is a welcome return to the slasher genre and perhaps the best Halloween sequel we have ever had.

What's so interesting about the 2018 "Halloween" is that it directly follows 1978 original and disregards the events in any other sequels or reboots. I have only seen the original and haven't heard particularly good things about most of the sequels, so I decided just to go ahead and watch this new one. I personally think the original movie is one of the best horror movies I have seen and think it builds suspense masterfully. While I do feel this movie has a different feel to it being newer and clearly bigger budget, it doesn't have the same impact that one does. That's not to say the movie isn't fun, because it definitely is. When it comes to any tense scene in the movie I thought the directing was handled very well. I also liked how it explored how the events of the classic movie can really mess up a person and Jamie Lee Curtis did a great job portraying someone who grew up to be rightfully paranoid. However, this movie has some oddly placed humor that feels more obnoxious than just as comedic relief. Nonetheless, this is a fairly entertaining movie that has a handful of great moments that had me on the edge of my seat.

It's clear from the opening credits that director David Gordon Green desires not only to pay tribute to the John Carpenter original (which also serves as the ONLY accepted background for this sequel.) but also wants to reanimate and bring back some kind of luster to this series which had been literally rotting away in an unholy mess of reboots, remakes and misguided sequels. No more are we expected to believe that Laurie Strode (A formidable Jaime Lee Curtis returning once more to her iconic role) is Michael Myers' sister like it was established way back in HALLOWEEN II, or worse yet, that Myers is some part of some cultist plan to bring back Samhain. 

This time, Laurie strode, in pure Sarah Connors fashion, has prepared all her life for Michael Myers' return. Her house off the grid is booby-trapped to the hilt, and she spent years training her daughter (Judy Greer) to be ready for such a confrontation, until she was taken by the State at the age of 12. She, however, has not embraced her mother's paranoia, and has tried her best to keep her own daughter (Andi Matichak) away from this insanity. Of course, Laurie's fears were justified as Myers manages to escape during a transfer to another facility. (The scene where Curtis witnesses the bus carrying Myers leaving the mental institution is especially poignant. Her acting being assisted by everyone on the crew that night wearing a "We are Laurie Strode" name tag). Of course, we have to accept that Myers was eventually captured after his disappearance at the end of the 1978 film.

Although director David Gordon Green is not known as a horror director (having being at the helm of stoner comedies like YOUR HIGHNESS and PINEAPPLE EXPRESS, and dabbling in a pretty decent inspirational drama with STRONGER), and claims to be respecting the original film, he does stray from Carpenter's bloodless approach in the 1978 movie by offering a healthy dose of onscreen violence and gore. Something to attract the kids and the Blumhouse fans, no doubt. 
Nevertheless, it's refreshing to see Michael Myers back as a simple, mindless embodiment of evil. Not a vengeful sibling. Not a troubled child from a white trash upbringing. Just a relentless killing "shape". (with director Nick Castle once again donning the discolored Captain Kirk mask.) And it's also a plus to see John Carpenter himself back at the music, adapting his unforgettable 1978 score with his son Cody Carpenter, and his godson Daniel Davies, both of whom are part of his band on tour, and have contributed to his albums LOST THEMES I and II. I'd be lying if I said that hearing his music over the trailers didn't create in me a strong desire to go see the film just for that very reason. Carpenter's involvement also extends to being executive producer and creative consultant. 

The script by Danny McBride and Green is streamlined enough, yet one can question the motivations of journalist Aaron Korey (Jefferson Hall), whose obsession with Myers presses him to do something stupidly reckless, under the watchful eyes of Myers' psychiatrist Dr. Sartain (a rather cartoonish Haluk Bilginer). The good doctor is also the focus of the only truly groan-inducing scene of the film, which sets up a concept similar to one unconvincingly explored in the previous films. One can only hope it will be abandoned in the now announced sequel.

The one thing the script gets right is the interactions between the three women stalked by Myers. There is no denying that there is a certain amount of satisfaction in seeing three generations of women fight back against an assailant who resurfaces after 40 years. The timing couldn't be more appropriate, considering some of the political headlines that have been pretty influential on the upcoming midterm elections. In Green's HALLOWEEN, the Strode women are done being victims, and will turn from prey to predator. The victims who fight back against the monster is nothing new; Nany confronted Freddy at the end of NIGHTMARE ON ELM STREET (1984, Wes Craven), Ripley kicked the Alien mother's ass in ALIENS (1986, James Cameron), and so on. Yet at this moment in time, Laurie Strode standing up to her attacker feels more pertinent than ever. 

Who would have thought that 40 years after his initial carnage, Michael Myers would find some kind of relevancy in the #metoo era.

I was genuinely excited to watch this movie and I went in fully expecting to love it. However, I can only describe the movie as an utter disappointment. 

The movies biggest sin is it's attempt to deceive the audience in a way that makes no sense at all. The crutch being that the subterfuge was meant for the movies antagonist Michael, yet the set up is something that Michael would never have seen making the entire premise pointless. 

The second biggest sin of the movie is it somehow spends a hour and thirty minutes achieving absolutely nothing. This time could of been spent exploring Laurie's time after Michael and how this effected her relationship with her daughter. Yet, apparently the creative team behind the movie felt like a 30 second montage was enough to cover this crucial plot point. 

Now, the above could of been forgiven to degree if the movie was at least a decent slasher movie, but apparently it couldn't even manage that. The entire movie lacks any sense of tension and Michael's rampage of killings is a bore. Even the iconic music failed to recreate the unsettling atmosphere of the original. 

The general premise of the movie was fantastic and I honestly believe this movie could of been something really special, but somehow they managed to squander all of it's potential.

A fun horror ride that's as amazing as it's original counterpart makes not only a great movie night but a great film for fans of this horror icon hopefully the next 2 final installments of this trilogy finally give us a proper end to the classic Myers saga and maybe opens the doors for crazy parallel universes (not connected to this trilogy of course) having Michael face off against other protagonists and new threats/challenges but that's something to talk about on a later know if something like that even happens

For now I'm just happy to see a critically and fan loved film that may finally give us a definitive ending to this franchise

Whilst I did enjoy this and it took me back to watching the original Halloween, there are too many plot issues for this to be anything above a 3/5 for me. This film certainly doesn't deserve any ratings above 3.5/5 because of objective flaws in the plot. For example, Michael gets shot multiple times and run over and yet remains completely fine. Michael has extraordinary strength which makes no sense considering he's been kept under lockdown and I doubt he's been exercising much - he doesn't even run anywhere he just walks everywhere. A lot of the plot is predictable - Michael going after the documentary people to get his mask, the doctor losing his mind, etc. The idea that Laurie has been training her whole life and booby traps her home because she expects Michael to escape is just dumb. There are some weird actions that are completely illogical such as Laurie turning off the lights in her house when she expects Michael to come - surely you want to be able to see the intruder rather than wandering around in the dark? Keeping the remote control to the basement on the side right next to the basement entrance is stupid. Apparently, this film also ignores the sequels (which I haven't watched because they have awful ratings) but maybe that's a good thing. The cinematography and soundtrack were great, and so were some of the action sequences but this film isn't what I'd consider 'horror' it's more of just a crime thriller about a weirdo in a mask. It isn't a bad film, the plot just ruins it somewhat.

Whilst the plot of the movie was intriguing, the end product wasn't. Far too many unrealistic injuries. Victims were killed quickly whereas Michael was shot twice and ran over and he was fine. And he took a crowbar to the head and didn't pass out or bleed and yet when he smashed a man's head against the wall, it gushed with blood and left him unable to assist his girlfriend. Either Michael Myers is an almighty being with no blood to escape his body when he is hit, or the movie was just not realistic. 

And if you'd been waiting for years to kill him, you wouldn't bolt the door, you'd just shoot him.

The 2018 reboot of Halloween is what happens when you don't let good things die. Yet, like Michael Myers, the series can't seem to die. Everything that made the originals so good, this film disregarded.

This is the first movie I debated on walking out on after paying for. I even tried to force myself to sleep through it at one point. It's that bad.

I liked the brutality of the death scenes and the homages to the original films. But that is where the things I like about this movie end.

Don't believe me? Watch the intro scenes before the title screen. It's anticlimactic. After that, the movie is a borefest of boring dialogue until Michael gets his mask. Expect about 30 minutes of endless talking before that happens.

The film also writes out all the sequels past 1978. This by itself should be a crime. The writing-out makes Michael Myers seem to be another random serial killer. The obsession that people in the movie have towards him now makes no sense. There are worse serial killers than Michael Myers since 1978. This single writing out of past movies destroyed my suspension of belief. The Halloween universe now makes no sense.

With the writing-out comes Laurie Strode's representation. This is a conflicting one for me. Though I appreciate the use of the original actor, her character makes no sense now. No explanation is made to how Laurie could afford her home and lifestyle. With someone who suffers from severe PTSD and paranoia, I doubt she could hold a job for long. Let alone affording all the things she has in the movie. Also, how would she know that Michael Myers is coming back? I understand the emotion involved, but she couldn't have been so prepared. The fact that she stayed so armed to the teeth removes a lot of tension.

One thing that made the originals so scary was how defenseless each protagonist is against Michael Myers. Having someone who is trying to hunt him down removes a lot of suspense.

Michael Myer's portrayal was one I didn't appreciate as much either. He seemed to be able to take damage more than he did in the other movies. The fact that he didn't seem as invincible as he was in the originals removed his aura of mystery and terror.

Then there are the "teenagers." The selection of the "teenage" actors is terrible. These actors are already wrinkling and look like they're about to hit thirty. Their dialogue was cringe-worthy and reeks of pandering. Slang words are fake or outdated. Attempts at jokes were not funny. The party and dancing scenes is cringey at best. This movie could cut 90% of the high school scenes and nothing of value will be lost.

While we're on the actors, let's talk about the deaths. While most were brutal and satisfying. Some deaths didn't make sense. There are places where people could have outrun Michael Myers. In such instances, the movie hides their deaths and shows dead bodies after. I know how Michael Myers walks, and it's not fast at all. Lazy writing if you ask me.

Speaking of lazy writing, let's mention jumpscares. I hold special hate towards is unnecessary jump scares where no one is in danger. Those, to me, signal cheap thrills that are the same as a sucker punch. If I get a jumpscare, something crucial has to have happened. This movie has those unconsequential jumpscares, often.

If you want real terror in horror movies, look at the ones who do suspense building well. The sense of not knowing what will happen next lead us to want resolution, even if it means scaring us. Imagine Alfred Hitchcock's "bomb under the table" example. This movie lacks the original tension building that the 1978 original did so well.

One tool that helps build suspense is music. That's an area this film lacked in. Shame, since the original was so good at using a musical score to build suspense and add tension. The music score that made the originals so terrifying is not there in this movie. Plenty of scenes were lacking. "Scary" scenes are now no longer scary.

I doubt I can go much further without spoiling the movie. But you get the picture.

Halloween 2017, part of the continued recent push for bad-sequel erasing rebootquels, is one of the best movie sequels and probably the best horror sequel ever. (Feel free to contradict me, I haven't put a lot of thought into that.)
It's fun, shout out loud satisfying slasher horror, surprisingly gory but not overly gory, a romp, both true to the original character and expanding and supporting a more modern Jamie Lee Curtis and japes with her family. 
There's a janky opening, but like the rest of the movie, it may have been a great bait and switch with the horror slasher tropes, as soon as the old font and music kicks in you know what you're in for; Something old, something new, some things borrowed, someone choked blue. 
I cheered every time they homaged the original because it was always testeful, and well edited in, its shot and written breaking the fourth wall, but the characters don't at all. 
The whole "say something" conceit didn't really track for me, but Halloween 2017 is a well intentioned, layered and balanced horror film, dealing with real world issues woven between the slow moving freight train inevitability of Michael Myers.

What a colossal disappointment of a sequel to one of the greatest horror movies of all time. I won't say greatest horror movie "franchises" of all time however, because admittedly the 'Halloween' movies have had many missteps within their film-canon, which I suppose are now no longer canon. That is probably for the best, with the 1978 'Halloween' being a classic then it deserves worthy additions to the franchise, if it even needs any (which it doesn't), although the 2018 'Halloween' did nothing but sully its legacy in my opinion. Where do I even start. The acting is nothing special, in fact there are some pretty terrible cases of it. Jamie Lee Curtis is really the only good part of this movie. A wonderful actress trying her best with the script given to her. While I mention the script, it's awful... Cringe-worthy and out-of-place comedy scattered throughout, compromising any possible suspense or seriousness that the movie tries to build; which it could barely muster up in the first place. The tone is all over the place, bouncing back-and-forth between non-scary horror to un-funny comedy. Also some of the choices made in the film are ridiculous, and any new characters introduced into this Halloween universe, which is nearly all of them in this movie; are either boring, plot-devices to propel the already lazy plot forward, or poor "comic-relief". I really don't like being this negative about movies, because movies are truly a passion of mine, and to be fair if this was a standalone horror movie and not trying to be a sequel to one of horror's classics then I probably wouldn't be as hard on it. Although due to it failing so miserably in my opinion at sufficing as a worthy sequel, I'm going to say this is really bad. I used to think this was a 3/0, but the more I think about it the sadder I am to see how much potential it squandered. The only thing keeping this from being unwatchable is Jamie Lee Curtis' performance and maybe two really cool cinematography shots. If you're a fan of this movie, there's nothing wrong with that. I just wish I was.
2/10

The Halloween franchise is as messy and confusing as that of the X-Men franchise, with many branching timelines finding many different realities for a man in a Shatner mask to stab people. This most recent attempt to revive one of the earliest progenitors of the ‘crazy man stabs teens' genre of horror films, opts to entirely ignore everything after John Carpenter's celebrated 1978 original, and show the effect of that film's events on Jamie Lee Curtis' Laurie Strode. Curtis is excellent as the battle-hardened Strode, the kind of terrifying grandma we all deserve. Judy Greer is also brilliant (when is she not?) as Laurie's distant daughter. It's when the film attempts to make me care about teenagers that it falls down, because I just don't. When you've a compelling story about a strained mother/daughter dynamic and 40 years of trauma, the only thing the teens can be is fodder that makes me feel nothing when they get moidered. Also, by removing the preceding films, the connection between Laurie and Michael is diluted. Why would he be obsessed with her for all these years if they'd only had a single encounter? Yes, he's crazy, but in building up their final confrontation, the film benefits from the years of clashes between the two characters without actually accepting that they exist. That said, it's a scary film, truly showing the single-mindedness of Michael Myers, and turns him into an unstoppable force of nature. And that theme music… ooooh baby it's one of the best ever.

2018's ‘Halloween' relies so heavily on nostalgia for the original and the Michael Myers mythos to draw a crowd that it seems to have forgotten to present us with a decent story to go with it. Even Jamie Lee Curtis can't bring this one back to life.
As a stand alone film, I enjoyed it. But, as a sequel it's meh.

I barely watch horror films.  This wasn't just- scary at all.

This was a cut above most slasher movies, and I did try to love it, but at the end it was merely acceptable given its reputation. I was hoping for something excellent, shooting for the stars if you will, and I landed on the moon. The music was excellent, and the old guy did a good job portraying Myers, but I really wasn't enamored with Curtis's performance - given the choice to make Myers not her brother (which I hated), it didn't really make sense for her to suspect that a then-6-year-old would eventually break free and try to kill her again. It's as though the movie wanted us to recognize the history the two had with his repeated returns to kill her in the retconned sequels, but didn't want to acknowledge their timelines. The heavy emphasis on guns wasn't intriguing. I actually liked the dialogue, particularly the brief moments with the little black kid. Some of the kills Michael bothered with didn't make sense - I get him killing the people that had his mask, but for him to bother killing a household just to get a kitchen knife didn't seem realistic.

It took a paradox for the concept of this film to work. The original Halloween was easily the best film in the series, but it would not have been a famous horror franchise without it's inferior successors. But this would not have worked if it wasn't a big horror franchise. So this movie needed all the sequels so they could ignore them. It should not have worked, but it did. The original created all the horror tropes we know today without knowing it at the time. Many horror films followed the same pattern for slasher flicks but this film was able to take the tropes it created and do something completely original. It took its original score which was never truly expanded upon in the other films, and created something even better. It didn't feel predictable and turning it into a thriller was a good move. We got to see Michael more than in any other, which should not have worked, but it did. It kept true to the original concept of The Shape while still being able to reinvent the character, or lack there of. The idea of him being a mindless killing embodiment of evil is much more scary than being obsessed with killing his last remaining family members, which every single sequel and reboot film relied heavily on. This is an example of the over-saturated sequels, reboots and prequel phase of cinema being done right. Any concept can get over done but it is movies like these of which this concept was made for.
Relatively forgettable entry in the franchise. Was a fun watch but didn't really bring anything new to the horror genre.

Short Take: Despite some good scenes here and there as well as a compelling showdown between the main characters and convincing acting by the lead, this movie falls tragically short of what it attempted to do, which was recreate the glory of the original Halloween and become a solid conclusion to the Saga. Basically, I would consider it no better than any of the sequels it attempted to blow out of the water. 
Review: While being a long time fan of the franchise and an expert on the Halloween movie series I certainly enjoyed watching this film, as I have mostly every single one in the series (despite how bad some are), this movie is among the worst ever in the entire saga of Halloween pictures. 
Certainly better than either of Rob Zombie's films, but of roughly the same quality of Halloween 5 and 6, Halloween fails to do what it set out to do, which was become a solid sequel of the original one. 
While I certainly commend the filmmakers for attempting to create a sequel that would be superior to all the ones ever made and to drift away from the genuine pieces of garbage that were Rob Zombie's films, the reality is that their attempt falls tragically short. 
Despite some good scenes here and there, particularly the one of the murder of the drunk kid in the grounds of a mansion, as well as that in the Hospital when Michael is presented his mask, as well as the personal vendetta the sheriff has against Michael,   as well as creating a heroine that, for the first time in all Halloween films, is a genuine foe to Michael Myers and provides an actual strong and worthy adversary, and a masterful acting job by Jamie Lee Curtis (particularly portraying someone who suffers from PTSD) the movie has a lot more negative aspects than it does positive.
In terms of characters, there is no development whatsoever. Aside from Laurie Strode, whom we know from other movies, all the characters are simply flat. The pathetic attempt for a new Dr. Loomis fails miserably and angers the viewer, as his rudimentary attempts at a revolutionary psychiatric treatment are straight out of fantasyland. The three generations of Michael Myers hunters (except for Laurie) is also completely lifeless and dull, and the sherriff, who seems to be the only characters genuinely motivated to stop Myers out of sheer virtue and righteousness, is not given enough time to become the hero he deserves to be due to a stupid plot twist that leaves the viewer shaking his head in total negligence for the screenwriter and director, who did everything to shoot themselves in the foot. 
Structurally, the film is poorly paced. Aside from the fact the whole shenanigan regarding the investigative journalists takes up a good chunk of screen time via a set up that is simply too long to create and could have been used in a much better way, the suspense is simply underwhelming. Of course, there are points where you do feel on the edge of your seat, but those points fail to climax, and all one can feel is frustration. Repeatedly, through the movie, you see scenes in which you naturally expect something bombastic to happen, but it never really does, therefore, you feel empty and wondering when the hell something worthwhile will happen. 
Furthermore, the movie is so poorly paced that it feels as though there is no second act. There is only a long first act and a short third act in which the victim and victimizer confront each other for yet another cliché Halloween ending. Of course, it's nice for the Killer to be set up in a trap, but there are so many plot holes in that final showdown, such as questions like 
Why didn't Laurie Strode truly fortify her cage?" and "Why doesn't she just shoot him with a hand grenade?" that it too, is ultimately unsatisfying. 
In addition, some of the supporting characters are so pathetic that you're almost glad when Michael wipes them away. The movie fails to do anything it anticipated, desired, or planned, and while there are some worthy scenes, the reality is that it fails, and that it does so miserably. To be honest, the movie trailer promised a film that was not delivered.

As someone who loves the original Halloween movie, I was wondering how they were going to bring this sequel into the light.
And oh boy I wasn't disappointed one bit. If you thought Michael was messed up in the original (or in any of the rancid sequels) think again. Michael Myers is back and more brutal than before, ready to finish what he started: Hunting and killing Laurie, the only one to escape death at his hands (or.. knife) 40 years ago. 
As for Jamie Lee Curtis as an older Laurie... oh boy did I like her. A lot. She really shows a lot of care not only for her safety but for the safety of her family too. If I had such a badass and protective mother/grandmother... life would be so good.
Yeah, the new doctor who replaces Samuel Loomis (R.I.P Doland Pleasence) is pretty much just a bland pumpkin for Michael to step on (literally) but let's be serious, he's not Loomis. And we're here just for Michael and Laurie. And we surely get what we want.

This is the best possible way they could have rebooted the franchise: to retcon of the events of the less successful movies and start fresh, making a direct sequel to the original film that started it all. This entry in the franchise lets Laurie have more agency over the outcomes of the film and proves that final girls can be badasses, even 40 years after the original film.

Halloween (2018) is arguably the best Halloween sequel in the Halloween franchise. The filmmakers created a beautiful film that dived deep into generational trauma and the effects it has on the surrounding environment of those with trauma. The film doesn't focus on Michael Myers 100% of the time, and that's something that great about this film. The Halloween franchise is over 40 years old and we have explored Michael in everyway. This film was a great way to focus on the main character, the final girl from 1978, than Michael - as a whole. Halloween (2018) pays tribute to John Carpenter's Halloween. This film is all nostalgic yet so original. This is nonstop suspenseful, and Michael Myers is the scariest he has ever been.

It doesn't make sense to portray Lori Strode as raving paranoid about Michael's return to kill her (to the point that she lost custody of her daughter), if Halloween 2 and Halloween H20 never happened in this film's continuity. Those films present the ONLY real reasons for the Lori Strode character to fear his return: 1) the sibling connection and 2) his return 20 years after the original proving that he is hellbent on killing Lori. But Halloween 2018 throws away those timelines, meaning that she's merely a random survivor of one single killing spree in 1978 and he's been under lock & key the 40 years since, so there is ZERO logical reason Lori would ever think he would return specifically for her; unless the Lori Strode character is so weak-willed that she allowed the trauma to destroy her mind, which I don't want to believe of our first Halloween heroine. Furthermore, the deaths are absurdly anti-climactic. There are two scenes where Michael strolls into someone's house and sticks his knife through people's necks or other body parts in under 10 seconds with zero build-up. The scene where Michael kills the young boy's babysitter at least attempts to build up some suspense, but the moment he begins stabbing her, all the horror is undercut by the little boy donning the "sassy black boy" archetype and shouting "Oh, shit!" which is clearly meant to be a comedic line. Why would they attempt to insert COMEDY in the middle of Michael's murder? Wouldn't one expect that to be an obvious faux pas for any horror movie, let alone a sequel to one of the greatest of all time? Furthermore, why are we supposed to care about Lori's new family, when this is now the 4th Halloween continuity timeline that replenishes new characters like recyclable cardboard boxes? Does their life or death even matter? They've already thrown away the entire existence of many characters we were supposed to root for in previous films like Jamie Lloyd and John Strode. So now all new characters feel like placeholders. The opening scene is one of the most laughable, nonsensical sequences I've ever laid eyes on. What is shouting at a mental patient with his 40 year-old murder mask meant to accomplish? What does getting him to talk even matter to anyone? However, I give the film major props for the twist of Michael Myers' doctor aiding Michael's murder spree by killing the police officer -- that was a very surprising, convincing, and thrilling twist that added extra horror to a film that badly needed it.

While there is a lot to like about this film, it had a number of the same shortcomings as the first one, which I found more forgivable because it was a different era in movies. The characters aren't interesting or likable, and they make idiotic and totally unrealistic decisions. I appreciate the fact that they made the story largely about female empowerment and how women deal with trauma, but that loses its efficacy when Laurie, who's spent 40 YEARS preparing for their 2nd encounter, once again makes numerous mistakes that almost gets her, and her family, killed. Like really, you forgot to bar the windows on your front door? Of all places? 

There are some great scare scenes, the tension is built well, and there are some nice callbacks and an interesting, though predictable, twist. Like, I'd watch it again, but I'd be yelling at the screen a lot, once again. Is it too much to ask for writers and directors to assume intelligence of their audience, and their characters?

I really wanted to like this movie a lot more, being a big fan of John Carpenter's original, but I can only say it's okay or fair. It starts out pretty strong, with an unsettling opening scene and elements like the title sequence being a direct homage to the original film ("Halloween III" playing on a TV is great call back to the first "Halloween" playing on a TV in "Halloween III") but some questionable choices get made and it seems to lose its way as the movie progresses. The characterizations of several characters are inconsistent, switching back and forth between badass and panicky. The lead teenage character who we think the torch is going to be passed to just doesn't cut it. And the end is quicker than I would have expected, feeling a little unsatisfying and reminiscent of "H20".

See it if you're a fan of the series. Others may be left feeling a little letdown.

I was really hyped for this movie because I love the Halloween series. However, by writing out all the other movies destroyed this movie. Taking away the super natural aspect of Michael Myers the other movies built up made this movie a big flop. In this movie he was just a random crazy person, who once free from prison just walk around slashing people. The kills had absolutely no scare aspect to them. 
They also ruined Laurie Strode in this movie by making her a complete loon after only the events of the first movie. I can see if she went crazy if it followed after H20, but since none of them never happened, then get over it. 
H20 did her significantly better. She was still paranoid but still a normal person. Also the three generations of strode woman was pretty cheesy.
But back to the major hole in the movie. Michael Myers. No scare aspect to him. It was just him roaming the street killing randomly to make it a gore fest. The writers really need to rewatch the older movies to learn the build up to the kill is one of the most dramatic. 
They could have done much better. However, due to how well the movie actually did, I worry the next two they plan will follow the same mistakes.

A tremendous follow up to the original film here. First, Jamie Lee Curtis is very good here returning to the role that made her a household name. There is such a tender, yet hard shell to her that has molded her into this confrontation with Michael and Curtis is superb at showing that. David Gordon Green also does a fine job of keeping this sequel in line spiritually with everything that made the original such a timeless classic. Carpenter also makes a grand return to the series and his music contributions are the difference. Most of his compositions are beautifully realized and utilized in the areas of the film they need to be. From the suspense side, there is truly none of the sequels that have done as well as this film in building up to the final act. Some further character building would have been welcome, but overall this is a solid follow up to what I consider the greatest slasher ever made. I am very much looking forward to seeing where they go with the next sequel.

A return to form for the franchise after the endless amount of dismal sequels, combined with Green's direction, the script co-wrote with McBride and Fradley, the performances of the cast, the score by John and Cody Carpenter and Daniel Davies, Simmonds' cinematography, Alverson's editing, Wright's production design, Ricker's set decoration, Gunshor's costume design, action sequences and visual effects, Halloween wipes away the dismal results of previous installments and creates new canon material!!!
