Been waiting for this for a year because it was meant to be a sober, serious scary film. Instead Michael was more super human than ever, surviving various assaults like Freddy Krueger, Laurie is a penniless alcoholic who cant cope with a family dinner without stealing peoples wine yet has built a Home Alone style death trap mansion that has easy access windows and to top it off theres a wacky psychiatrist who lets podcasters scream at his patients before jumping the shark half way through. I know from that opening sequence that they'd done what they said they weren't going to. I wasn't prepared for the humour which they said wouldn't be there or the fact that the film didnt have a significant plot and was mostly concerned with recreating nods to the previous films. Easter eggs are great when you have to find them but not when they make up the basic plot. They also made an unforgivable mistake with the marketing - put out so much footage, including the death of a major character in the final act, that I had seen most of the plot. There was virtually nothing that was a surprise because of it. And worst of all they allowed the finale to be described in the iTunes track listing sp I knew what happened weeks before I saw it. Its been a hit because of fans like me and dumb teens who dont know what they are watching but I consider this an insult to those of us who have stuck by it. They should have spent a year getting the script into a far better shape. This was such a disappointment.
Awesome. The way it should end!!
The best Halloween movie ever. Could have had better actors though.
Extremely predicable. Hardly scary in the least. Acting was not terrible, but the story was weak. Makes me wonder what qualifications movie studio executives must have in order to keep their jobs.

Loved it for the most part.  The two things I absolutely hated is the angle of the doctor wanting Michael to live SO bad that he murders the officer. And the thing that lost a whole star for me is that they had the guts to make a new Halloween movie, but didn't have the guts to go through with killing him. I've never been so mad at a movie. Other than those two things, I loved it.
Entertaining and enjoyable! Had fun throughout the whole movie!

I'd have to say this movie itself is a worthy sequel to the original than all its campy predecessors (I actually enjoyed a few things about Halloween II more than this one but oh well). The kills and suspense was well laid out, not that much stupidity, but they certainly could have explored more of the crazy doctor from Smith's Grove & his obsession with Michael instead of having him killed off instantly. Laurie's years of building a bunker and boobie traps paid off well for a third, final act. Overall, it was worth the watch with mostly all of the homages that were parallel to the original as the icing on the cake!

Abject.
With plot and characterisation almost as plodding as the utterly implausible villain, this was about as exciting as a league two goalless draw. 
There's nothing scary about a slow moving giant trudging through a neighbourhood knifing everyone misfortunate enough to cross his path. It's just tedious.
The only thing that rivals this for disappointment is the "festival" of Halloween itself.
The best sequel in the series to the original. It both pays tribute to John Carpenters 1978 Halloween while putting its own modern spin on the franchise. Absolutely loved every minute of it!
ok I'm not a fan of slasher movies but this was great. the whole movie has you waiting in anticipation and the kills were entertaining. overall would recommend

It's a shame 'slasher' movies aren't held to a higher standard.  The few good things in this movie were taken from the first film, and not everything they paid homage to  played well in this one. The kid the girl is babysitting is great! he's really the only character who is both likable and believable... but he's only around for a couple minutes. Everyone else just says and does weird stupid things in between some of the most traumatizing death scenes I've seen in a while.

Overall this was a very good horror movie. As with most horror movies, you have to suspend reality and enjoy the ride. A few inconsistencies and overall unrealistic parts, but an enjoyable ride nonetheless. Oh, and Michael Meyers is still scary as hell after 40 years!
I think its a great movie and I recommend it.
The movie had a great tone! Provided a very solid story, with decent acting all around!
Best of the Halloween sequels. While throwing out all the previous sequels - including II - it still gives a nod to them by way of some fun Easter eggs
I CANT WAIT TO SEE THIS MOVIE OMGGGG

Michael is at his absolute best since the 1978 Original Classic.  The same can be said about the score by John Carpenter and his son.  Jamie Lee Curtis takes over the screen on multiple occasions.  Although the story has some questionable decisions, it does have a heart, which is more than can be said about most of the sequels.  At the end of the day, we watch these movies to see Michael, and when he is on the the screen, it is truly captivating.
it was alright. love Michael Myers but I enjoyed the rob zombie films much more
Terrible. Not at all scary. Boring. Stupid plot that didn’t make much sense. Did I mention it wasn’t scary?

As a true sequel to the original John Carpenter masterpiece, it does hold up well.  My only complaint is that in the original there seemed to be a method to the killing spree.  This outing Michael Myers pretty much carves his way through the streets of Haddonfield as a simple psychopathic killer.  The body count is high with a few (very few) kill effects and at the very least the suspense level is high without being over burdening.  I was lucky enough to see the original opening weekend in 1978 and was gratified to watch the audience reactions to what was on the screen.  This one was simply another sequel with no surprises.  I still give it a high rating and applaud Mr. Carpenter and Miss Curtis for perhaps putting an end to the series.  Let's see something new for a change.

Disappointing doesn't begin to describe this lazy, empty excuse for yet another "sequel" to the original.  Ignores everything that made the 1978 classic so memorable.  That film was eerie, it had atmosphere, it was patient, it had purpose.  Despite somehow fooling critics into giving this film mostly positive reviews, I was honestly more impressed with the sloppy 1981 Halloween II.  That movie was also guilty of replacing atmosphere with brainless violence.  But it did at least attempt to continue the story and feel of the first movie.  I am not defending Halloween II, it's not a good movie.  But, it is a better sequel than this movie is.  Exceedingly violent, it even turns Michael into a very creative sadist, pulling out people's teeth and turning them into human jack'o lanterns.  This Michael Myers HAS had 40 years to brood and become more inventive.  But part of what made him so creepy in 1978 and 1981 was, he wasn't elaborate in his pathology.  He simply killed people without remorse or hesitation.  He did, however, seem to have a reason or some sense of purpose, especially in the first movie.  Here, he kills anyone and everyone and is prolific - this is high-volume, high-violence, more is better because we are all so desensitized we need smushed heads and graphic deaths every 3 minutes.  Even the reimagined Lori Strode and her 3 generations of survivor women isn't fully or effectively realized.  It could have been.  The opportunity was here, yet again, and I have the feeling this is the last chance for Lori and Michael to square off on October 31.  It's pretty sad, actually.  Any true fan of the original would likely reject this overcooked slop and send it back.
I loved it! Totally hit all the classic Michael Meyers but added in some even scarier elements.  Loved the little humor here or there. He's a big fear of mine and this definitely didn't disappoint.

The movie all round was an excellent addition to the halloween franchise, using the first movie as a basis and essentially removing every movie after from the franchise, removing the supernatural aspects of Michael Myers and restoring him to what he originally was, and "mentally deranged psychopath who was out for blood". Although the movie was never the less a wonderful sequel to the first, the movie had a few down points, for example parts of the movie relied on comic relief instead of suspense, such as the child that was being babysat who seemed to be just used to get a small few laughs from the audience in a scene , which if didn't had the child , would be a almost perfect scene. Another example is Michael's new doctor who instead of being a replacement of the late Donald Pleasance, was what seemed to be an obsessive "fan" who instead of wanting to contain the evil of Michael wanted to essentially wanted him to "Say something". Other than useless scenes and pointless tone drops the movie was a excellent story that the original directors (who mostly directed this addition) would be proud of, using familiar camera tricks, recreating the movies opening from the original, and using the outer focus to hide Michael from the audience. All together a amazingly enjoyable movie.
Absolutely predictably, feels like an old plot already!

A mixed bag. Halloween 2018 starts out strong, but goes downhill once a certain plot twist occurs. You'll know it when you see it. Also, use of humor can be walking a fine line. Humor works in Marvel films because one shouldn't take superhero films too seriously. Unfortunately, it doesn't work well too often in horror films because it lightens the mood/atmosphere. A horror film should smother you in it's dark subject matter. The last point is that while some kills were impressive, it is unnecessarily gory. The first Halloween and even the original Texas Chainsaw Massacre were not gory at all, but they were genuinely frightening because what they didn't show was left to the viewer's imagination making it even more disturbing. 
It's good to see Michael back and Jamie Lee is great, but to me, the true sequel to Halloween will always be Halloween 2. It doesn't get any more iconic in Halloween than Laurie shooting at Michael's eyes and the bloody "tears" coming out
A let down. Not impressed.

Blessed by a much more centered vision, a good cheesy-but-effective script and a surprisingly focused direction by David Gordon Green in his first horror take, this rehash of the disappointing sequels benefits the effectiveness of the first film, paying both tribute and respect, rewarding the audience with authentic thrills, great haunting environment and worthy esthetics to one of the genre's most iconic faces, never mind the inevitable clichés and useless plot points, but offering the best of Jamie Lee Curtis to enjoy.

After seeing for a second time this movie is the 2nd best to the original in the franchise. It makes Michael Myers scary again in so many ways. My only issue is the movie could of used time better when establishing  certain people and situations but this movie is very fun and I want to see the franchise move forward with this quality.

I am a true Halloween movie fan. This particular movie I wasn't to thrilled about at all. I'm used to these movies being scary and intense, this movie had funny parts that upset me. They could have shown an glimpse of Michael Myers face since he's older on this film. It was boring as well,  the only actor I appreciated was Jamie Lee Curtis. Also what was with this new Doctor killing because he was so obsessed with Michael. This movie just ruined my whole feeling about the Halloween movies period. ??

Great movie!! Better than Halloween 2? Maybe, however the movie's pacing issues are very noticeable. There are parts of the film that are just amazing and have a lot of potential, but there also ones that are just cringe for a Halloween film. Overall a good film... not great.
Meh...you've seen all of it before...

Great Twist Off , From Previous Halloween movie !! I'm was very anxious to see the movie and I can say it was decent but not as good as the previous movie ! I would recommend everyone that's a fan of Micheal Myers to definitely see the movie !
Refreshingly Simple, Halloween is tense and aggressive. It gets back to the core of what makes the original so great: it gives us characters we care about and a Michael Myers who we are terrified of.
It was not that scary and not as good as the original first movie 40 years ago
It is the best Horror movie sequel ever. It is Empire Strikes back of horror.

If you're a halloween fan this is definitely a must watch! I grew up with the series and halloween 1978 is still my all time favorite movie, it was followed however, by a lackluster halloween 2 that John Carpenter stated that he didnt want to make but it took him a 6 pack of beer every night to finish the script. Alongside that was the terrible thorn movies and the 20 years timeline. This new one erases everything except the original 1978 and does a fine job, a must see.
Just an OK script. Nice kills though.
Satisfying sequel finale to a legendary Halloween franchise.  See my full #moviereview at https://moviereviewmom.com/halloween-movie-review/

After a long wait to see Laurie back in action against Micheal, this was a great return to a franchise that I have loved since I was a kid. The film feels like it fits in with part one even after 40 years. The soundtrack is fantastic and Carpenter did a great job making the music part of the experience. My only reason for dropping it a star is because I feel like some of the younger characters could have been fleshed out more before they start getting killed off. Other than that it's a great film that should please both casual and hardcore fans.

Halloween isn't like most of the recent horror movies that have came out for the past few years. Michael Myers, who was terrifying three decades ago, is now, once again, terrifying. The movie starts with these two terrible reporters confronting Michael at his insane asylum. They pull out his murder mask, and all the other psychotic inmates have panic attacks at the sight if the mask. This scene alone sets up the tone of the movie. This shows that these already insane, psychotic people are terrified of this man, and because of that it's pretty terrifying to see them screaming and flipping shit. Of course, Michael escapes and murders quite a few people, and of course this sets Laurice off and she starts to freak out and try to protect her grandchild and her daughter. Seeing Laurice on edge throughout this entire movie is actually a very good thing to show, because in every other movie she's in, she has always been the person who was been strong and willing to fight. Anyway, blah blah blah, let's get to the meat and potatoes of the movie: Michael fucking Myers. Michael has jumpscares, I'm not going to say that he doesn't, but the majority of this movie is him being in the background, barely noticeable, and he starts to slowly move forward and closer to the victim. It's genuinely terrifying. Sometimes you can see his shadow and then he comes out of nowhere and stabs someone in the fucking neck. Laurice fighting Micahel in the final act was also set up so perfectly, I was in awe in the theaters. The cinematography accompanied by the soundtrack is the best I've seen in a while as well, and finally, I am going to go bakc to the earlier parts of the movie. When Michael finds the reporters, I was genuinely scared. The last horror movie that actually truly petrified me was IT (1990) and I was 6 when I originally saw it!

Yes, I have talked about the strengths of this movie, but there ate a few things that had gotten on my nerves to be completely honest. The first thing that annoyed me isn't exactly a big deal, but I really would've liked to have seen Michael wrecking the bus and escaping. Of course, this doesn't make the movie worse, but it's just me being nit-picky. Also, the characters are very, very, very stupid. Like literally retarded at some parts.
Like the original, a top notch THRILLER, this isn’t a horror movie but a grounded realistic violent thriller just like the original I LOVED IT!!!

Overall I would have to say that the movie was not at my expectations. I expected something better considering that it would have been the last movie to the sequel the Cliffhanger was pretty obvious at the beginning of movie but I feel like they definitely could have done better and overall just didn't really enjoy it and don't see how it could be ranked as a horror movie.

I went and saw it twice. This is the best entry in the franchise since the original. The opening scene was intense and painted the picture for the rest of the film: Michael has no explanation except pure evil. He is not specifically after anyone in this film but the forces at work pit him against Laurie and her family.
I felt the tension throughout. Nice breaks of comedy to settle the tone. The Shape is terrifying again which was missed. A great sequel. Loved it!!

Dissapointing overall, but by no means awful. The subplots were uninspired, the script was lousy at points, and some of the acting wasn't great. However, intense violence, good tension, and seeing Michael Myers on the big screen were all plusses. Thumbs down overall, but not terrible.
Amazing job with this movie!!!     I've already seen it 3 times and can't wait to see it again!

Incredibly cringy dialogue, predictable plot, bad acting, zero suspense, and not scary at all. It was dispointing and hyped up way to much. The characters were all completely stupid, even for a horror movie. 
The movie was also seemingly confused if it was a comedy or a suspense/horror. Every "scary" scene looked much more like something out of a campy B-movie comedy. 
The only redeemable factor about this film is the kid being babysat. Everyone else was either a terrible actor, or sleepingly boring.
Not as good as the original but loads better than those that followed!!!! A really great sequel to the original! Some scary moments but a great film overall!!!

Pretty enjoyable for Halloween fans. As long as you actually understand the premise of the movie it’ll make sense. It erases all other sequels. They didn’t happen, so it definitely has a different take. No family stuff at all.

I'm not gonna lie. I was quite afraid that Danny McBride and David Gordon Green would end up creating their distinctive kind of edgy dark gore comedy, pulling away from the mythology of the original movie.

I'm glad I was pretty wrong. 40 years later, this Halloween works as an almost perfect mirror of Carpenter's original piece. This is not only a thematic mirror but even a concrete visual one. Laurie Strode (Jamie Lee Curtis is just amazing) is the perfect echo of Michael Myers. She's the stalker of the light. She takes the boogeyman's place several times, but with a completely opposite intention.

This is a tale of empowerment of the victim in the #MeToo era. And for the fragile masculinities that can be somehow be bothered by this, don't worry: Good Ol' Mike meets a fairly large bloody quota.

My sole criticism with "Halloween" is its little commitment bookending the story, eliminating the possibility of creating a perfect duology. The chance of a direct sequel obviously implied a dose of bittersweet ambiguity.
I feel like they didn't really take their time with this one. To me it was more funny parts, and it didn't seem that scary like the others
Very well done movie. They kept it fairly believable.
It was good. Definitely not great. Nothing groundbreaking here.
Solid sequel for a slasher film.  Not as scary as you would have expected and followed most of the cliche.

Pros: Michael Myers looks fantastic in worn, rugged mask.

Cons: Everything else. Juvenile jokes on top of poor character decisions. This film isn't smart and I refuse to dumb myself down and leave my brain at the door.
No substance at all...

CHECK OUT OUR PODCAST, DYSFUNCTIONAL NERDCAST, FOR A COMPLETE SPOILER RIDDEN REVIEW.  NEW EPISODE COMING 10-22-18. ALSO, GO TO OUR PAST EPISODES FOR MORE MOVIE REVIEWS.  WWW.DYSFUNCTIONALNERDCAST.PODBEAN.COM
Amazing movie. It beats every Halloween movie aside from the original in 1978.

This movie is Pure Garbage How come they got rid of laurie strodes son from Halloween h20? This movie makes no sense at all I didn't believe she had a daughter and granddaughter only a son played by josh Hartnett !!!

Good enough. Slow, tame start. Fun ride in the middle. Let down ending, not worthy of a 2nd or 3rd rebooting of the franchise. Filmmakers should be held to higher standard - constantly rebooting is sloppy and uncreative. That being said, I enjoyed my time watching it. And the ending made me wonder about what happens next... but no outcome would be a good choice.
Absolutely worth every penny

A very serious disappointment with adolescent-level writing, an unbelievable plot twist, and details that make no sense.  Mike Meyers may be dead, again (JL Curtis chopped his head off in H20 ... so...I just don't get it!), but the worst news about this flick is there will most likely be a sequel.
GOOD WRITING - GOOD ACTING!  GOOD PLOT! Was this really a horror film? I was impressed!

Halloween 2018 has a strange transition from intro to credits which foreshadow the many tonal issues throughout the film. It fails to bat themes home and ends abruptly. It doesn't bring many new ideas to the table. That's all the bad, but there are still tons of brutal kills, scares and tense moments to entertain.

Fantastic transition to today's audience and keep the sequence perfectly aligned with 1978's Halloween. Still horrifying scary and even the joke in the film, with today's gun violence the knife in the wrong hands will still terrif a community.

While the film does not provide the subtleties the original 1978 film provides, it instead replaces it with brutality and skillfully balances the killings off screen and on screen. Some of the dialogue of the side characters does not hold up very well, but the performances by the main cast tend to negate that negativity. The score of the movie is skillfully executed as it is subtle and simple in nature but is integral to the film.  There are some plot holes, but those wanting to see a true return to Michael Myers should be pleased with the overall performance of the film.

I feel like a lot of kids or twenty somethings are boosting this movie up. There's no way seasoned fans of the horror genre can think this is that good of an installment. Maybe I'm the one getting old but the cheap laughs of a cussing ten year old, one liners from inebriated teens and dumb actions by ppl who should know better... I'm just over it.
I was a little disapointed, but still the best reboot of a franchise in years! Go see it if you bare it.
Outstanding latest version of the classic Halloween saga. Introduced a new generation to the film and was not disappointed. Very well done.
Michael Myers meets Sarah Connor minus the heart-pounding intensity. And after 40 years... we still don't know why Myers is on a must-kill-Laurie mission.

There's a problem with modern horror films... they aren't very scary. I found myself laughing at this film more than gasping. I found myself rooting for the protagonist but felt relatively unafraid of The Shape. There are a few clever shots where you need to search the frame in order to see The Shape but, otherwise I could see the scares coming a mile away. That being said, its better than most horror films I've seen made recently, this one just feels too restrained. When I go to a horror film, I'm looking to be scared and shocked because that's the point of horror films. It's not horrible, it's just not as great as it could have been.

Very disappointing. *SPOILER ALERTS* Could have been really good but plodded out every  stupid horror film cliche. Leaving the door open when a serial killer is on the loose. Check. Turning all the lights off when a serial killer is on his way to your house. Check. Stalking a serial killer IN THE DARK with a torch to a bloodstained cupboard when clearly he's behind you. Check. Having a secret cupboard but leaving the remote on the side. Check. Hiding in secret hiding place but then making a racket and blowing a hole in the floor above you. Check. Police men guarding you from a serial killer talking about ban mi rolls?! Really?! Standing surrounded by guns but not grabbing one when serial killer is directly outside your house. Yeah ok. Setting up sliding security shutters in the entrance to your bedrooms but not your front door?! Standing outside a front door WITH SMASHABLE GLASS PANES (?!) to try and listen for the man who wants to murder you? 
A huge disappointment.
Jamie Lee Curtis was one dimensional. Massive potential unfulfilled. 
Daughter and granddaughter portrayed as weak women. Why?! 
So disappointing. No back story of the

My kids dragged me to this and no surprise, it's GARBAGE.  They try to turn Jamie Lee into an Aliens-esq Signorney Weaver.  Michael is revealed too early and too much.  He is freaking walking around with his mask IN DAYLIGHT for god's sake!  His super-human feats, like kicking through the back of a police cruiser (I've tried it, it's NOT do-able.,..) are ridiculous.  Perhaps most disturbing was the passle of young kids in the theatre.  Gory psycho killer violence becomes cheap daycare.  What a pathetic society we have become.

Halloween was by far the best sequel of the series. almost becoming as faithful and dreary as the 1978 classic. Director David Gordan Green wastes no time on jumpscares and relies entirely on the strength of the "Boogy man" And at a "Me Too" time like this it is easy to trace this movie into a story about a woman coming to terms with her Male abuser after years of preperation. 10/10

So very disappointed. I actually walked out 30 min before ending.. The original Halloween is my favorite all time horror film and this was just awful. Not scary just campy. They got nothing right here.
Utter rubbish........walked out after an hour
This movie is what TRUE Halloween movie fans have been waiting for. John Carpenter just made a fool of everyone who has attempted to take the reigns of this franchise after his departure.

The first quarter of the movie is pointless. It goes into retelling the story of Michael Myers that we already all know or should know if you watched the original... Then the biggest issue of this movie is the characters. Majority of the characters have no meaning to the story line. I don't want to give spoilers away but I kept watching the movie wondering why these characters were created with no real purpose? And everything is too predictable and everything just comes too easy for Michael Myers... how he gets his mask back, how he finds Laurie, ect... I give it two starts because Jamie Lee Curtis puts on a great performance through all this.

Michael disappeared into the night and yet the just captured him. Not to mention but they don't want you to awknowlge the other movies yet they stole scenes from several of the sequels. As a huge Halloween fan, this came up short.

This is probably one of the truest horror sequels I have ever seen. The vision that David Gordon Green had for this movie makes the story of Laurie Strode, Michael Myers, and the babysitter murders seem so realistic and that honestly makes it creepier. In past Myer's sequels he has sort of become a cartoon character that the viewers root for but in this movie he is someone to be feared. Every detail of this movie made it feel real and terrifying. I saw it twice opening weekend and the second viewing was even better. Great direction and writing on this movie and glad to have Jamie Lee back, she did a great job portraying what her character had to deal with for 40 years...
I love Michael Myers, so I LOVED this MOVIE.  Jamie Lee Curtis tried way to hard to be tough I didn't like her in this movie.
Very well done! Once it gets rolling it just gets crazy until the end.

This movie is great.  5 stars.  Erasing the other sequels and starting over was a stroke of genius.  The original was so simple and effective.  A senseless evil lunatic with some supernatural abilities that made him difficult to stop and difficult to kill.  This new replacement sequel goes back to the basics and delivers. If you haven't seen the original, I'd recommend watching it first for context.  You'll need it to understand a few of the scenes in the sequel. JLC as Laurie Strode is the bomb, just as she was 40 years ago.  Make no mistake, there are only 2 Halloween movies-1978 and 2018.  Let the others slide into obscurity where they belong.
One of the best horror movies of recent years. If you are a halloween fan then you will love this! Plus that ending though, that ending!!!!!

This doesn't function well enough as a stand alone movie. It goes so far out of it's way to reference bits from every lousy sequel which in turn, makes for a movie jam packed full of rambling, unnecessary scenes. Luckily, it ends with a really powerful homage to the original in which Laurie and Michael hunt each other and it is so inspiring that it's enough to (almost) make you forget the rubbish first half.
This seguel is not the worst but it is not the best either, it is mediocre. Halloween II (1981) and H20 are way above this movie, Halloween III Season of the Witch is more scary than this sequel.
Loved it!  Nice balance of humor and scares.
Better than anything after 4 or maybe 5 but still not that good. Will probably age as poorly as H2O

While it's not my favorite Halloween it may very well be my favorite sequel in the franchise! JLC gives a fantastic performance and Michael Myers feels and looks just as he should. It's a great time to be a horror fan!
Great movie, the suspense was awesome. I loved it. would totally recommend watching!

At the beginning of the movie when the journalists visit Michael during the checkerboard scene I thought it was going somewhere into the psychological aspect of why he kills and who he chooses but when the guy broke out the mask it went down fast from there. How is a journalist going to obtain evidence in a crime if law enforcement even were still maintaining it as evidence. 
The dialogue from his doctor even mentions he wants to know why he kills and why he don't talk. Those questions were never answered and I think that would have made the movie more interesting. A lot of his victims had nothing to do with the story. They were just random. At one point he don't kill his doctor then the next time he does. 
They should have focused on why he kills and who, why he don't talk, and kept the story focused on Lori Strode and her daughters family and then tied all that together. 
I also didn't like that they basically remade scenes from the first movie but involved different characters doing the same thing. For example, in the first one Michael falls off the balcony and disappears shortly after. In this one Strode does. This happens several times throughout. I think the writers could have been more creative instead of copying something that has already been done.
This movie sucked balls.
Great movie! Only second to the original
Only dumb plot twist was with the doctor other than that was a great movie.

Get rid of all the other sequels and make this the official sequel to Halloween. The thing that made Michael Myers such a good horror icon was there was no rhyme or reason to why he kills. He just did. The other sequels tried to explain why he was like this and the best answer for this franchise is he's just evil. This movie went with that theme and it makes this sequel so much more intense and thrilling. Laurie Strode becoming obsessed from her trauma made so much sense. And the little nods throughout the movie were great without making them too much of a device to make it entertaining. Probably the best horror movie to come out in the last couple of years.

I watched the new Halloween over the weekend. Without any spoilers, I will say that I think it had such a missed opportunity to be great. I don't think people that try to remake or sequel Halloween understand what made the original so great. 

The original wasn't full of gore, the thing that made it scary was Michael Myers was mysterious and hidden through most of the film. You only saw brief glimpses of him but when he did appear on screen, it was startling and eerie. There was a genuine reason to fear him. 

Now filmmakers think showing him with extreme kill scenes with blood and gore make it a great horror movie. Doesn't work. Go back and make Myers mysterious and hidden and use him sparingly.  Too much of The Shape is not a good thing. 

I will say the movie started strong, but by the second half, it just kind of loses its way. There are plot lines that just make absolutely no sense. It's like "hey, let's just throw this in here just to surprise people" but it fails miserably. If you've seen it, you know what I'm talking about. If you haven't, you'll know it once you see it.

As a fan of the Halloween movie franchise this was a total disappointment for me. They omitted nearly everything that made Halloween, Halloween. Omitted every movie but the 1st one, down played Michael Meyers back story/history/legacy like he only had 5 kills on his record like it was just a random babysitter thing and he's been completely dormat for 40 yrs since. Then they took away the sibling backstory of him and Laurie which always gave the Halloween franchise it's depth/storyline. It seemed like his escape and finding laurie was simply opportunistic and not him actually obsessively and purposely hunting her down which is another thing that gave this franchise storyline/depth. It just lacked everything that made the Halloween franchise worthy of being a cult horror franchise for me. It also seemed strange for Laurie to spend 40 yrs prepping for him to come for her when they downplay it all like a random babysitter attack and no other kills since for that length of time. Without the sibling history, other escapes and kills it seemed out of place and again, like him escaping now and finding laurie and her family was purely opportunistic only, like he just stumbled upon them and it was all just coincidence. I think they had a great idea with showing laurie's ptsd, her survival instincts/final stand but it doesnt work when you take away all the substance that would make all that necessary. I had high hopes for this but now I'm just left frustrated.

Amazing movie ! Would have been perfect if the original Halloween score was added to chase scenes however it's very well written and produced! By far the best one after the original first 2! Great job Blumhouse! Please do one more!

Awful! Every single thing in it has been done better in other sequels. To be honest, I think Danny McBride wrote a sequel to Terminator and couldn't get a green light in that franchise. So he put in a couple name changes and switched it over to a Halloween sequel. This movie might work better for you if you've never watched another Halloween sequel. Even then, the suspension of disbelief is way over the top. Michael would be something like 67 at this point and have spent his entire life in an institution. That's not someone who's going to be physically intimidating. And in the original film, if we ignore the sequels, Michael's not physically intimidating, really. He's a looming presence always in the background. He sneaks and slunks around. Imagine this film if it were about a quiet old man who escapes a mental institution slyly and goes back to kill the one who got away. Imagine if Laurie were a nice old lady who-when confronted with the evil of her childhood-finds that strength again to do anything to protect her granddaughter. What would that movie have been? One that was a lot more relatable and not just realistic but also human than this hunk of garbage Terminator sequel.

It made me feel like it stuck with the original story line. For those that are looking for a movie that makes you jump alot (as the last 10 years of horror movies have done) this is not exactly that. It's  much more of a story that depicts what happens to people after such terrific things take place. A family that utterly is destroyed relational, mentally, and emotionally. In this sense, its terrifying to think what happens to people after such tragedy. As a person who is a fan of Halloween I love that they did not give into the cheesy scary movies that we are bound to nowadays. It's been 40 years since Michael Myers stalked Laurie Strode in Haddonfield, Illinois. Since then we have been subject to a slew of sequels, reboots and spinoffs, some of which Jaime Lee Curtis has starred in herself. Now comes Halloween 2018, 20 years after Halloween H2O and 40 years since the original film. This film stands as the TRUE sequel to the first film exploring what has happened to Strode and her family since the traumatic event. In what can only be described as a modern horor classic with tropes that evolve into truly terrifying and tense scenes with outstanding performances from the female cast and a modern twist on this classic tale that will have Halloween fans screaming for more.

Halloween is set in the current time with Laurie Strode (Jaime Lee Curtis) a complete shadow of the woman she was when we met her in the first film. She is battered, angry and essentially broken. She lives on the outskirts of town in her own fortress, completely obsessed with Michael Myers and his impending transfer to another prison. Her daughter Karen (Judy Greer) is hepling her own daughter Allyson (Andi Matichak) get ready to leave for college. Enter two British podcasters who want to interview Myers and Strode to gain new insight into these crimes (think Making a Murderer etc) who provoke Myers and unleash all hell on this unsuspecting community who are forced to relive these events from 40 years ago.



Going into this movie it was hard not to buy into the hype. The press junkets from Curtis have been captivating, audiences and critics are raving about the film, yet after the last few years of disappointing horror films it was hard to come into this with fresh eyes and still regain some shred of hope for this sequel (particularly after Laurie Stode's infamous death scene in Halloween Resurrection). What I loved most about this film is its constant nods to the sequels as well as other horror hits like Scream and I Know What You Did Last Summer. Having millenials point out the absurdity of people being so hung up on 5 deaths that happened 40 years ago compared to the horrors that our world faces today is something worth exploring. While they directly addressed it, it wasn't really explored any further than that. That being said the intensity of the murders and brutality of the death scenes are nothing short of spectacular. You can really feel the Blumhouse influence in the gore and confronting slasher scenes.

While this is all set in modern times, the score, soundtrack, camera shots and feel fresh out of the 1970's original. This is the perfect blend of modern and classic horror that make the film feel epic an very true to the series past. Curtis looks the part as a grandmother who is prepared to protect her family at any cost. Her haggard and rough portrayal perfectly match the home or really fortress in which she lives. Simiarly Karen has suffered a life of neglect and trauma due to her mother's paranoia and has a firm stance on not budging till Laurie gets professional help. This is then passed down to Allyson who is definitely the most sand of the three characters living a relatively carefree teenage life with clear sympathy and affection for her grandma, while her relationship with her mother is extremely strained. In the final act of the film where all three women come together to confront Michael Myers. It really cements their relationship and shows the generational trauma that this movie sets about to explain.



This film does have alot of intense and emotional moments, it was really hard to put nostalgia and all the love I have for the originalk film aside and treat this as its own thing. Sometimes the film goes out of its way to explain things that could have just been portrayed through actions and flashbacks rather than having a spoken narrative over the top. This is one part of the film that I didn't enjoy. Audiences are unfortunately treated like idiots at times and while this may be necessary for audiences who haven't seen the first film, it really takes you out of the film.

Overall Halloween 2018 is a true return to form after 20 years of sequels that pale in comparison to the original. While this doesn't quite reach the heights of the first film, it does get really REALLY close. Be prepared for some really intense moments and performances that are rare in a horror film (especially from Blumhouse!) Definitely don't see this alone, take your friends, your family and prepare for the return of Halloween and what is sure to be impending sequels for years to come. For the meantime enjoy this masterpiece in filmmaking and storytelling.

After several disappointing sequels and reboots, we finally got a good Halloween movie. While I felt a few characters were only there to die and they could've come up with a better title, it still had an interesting plot, great main characters, unique editing, scares that aren't cheap, and an amazing performance from Jamie Lee Curtis. It was a fun ride and one of this year's biggest surprises.

Michael was scary in a way of intense suspense which is how it should be. Jaime Lee Curtis was really good in the movie and so was most of the cast which was nice that I didn't have to see a bunch of bland characters like a basic horror movie. The doctor, the "new Loomis," was a neat addition and added a new kind of small twist. Some really good humor, too. I really liked the 2018 Halloween. Michael Meyers is back and I was really surprised how David Gordon Green and Danny McBride wrote a pretty damn good script. A few laughs. A lot of Easter eggs that pay homage to the previous movies. The kills were gruesome and even some some of off screen kills were cool(cop scene). Notable characters that you can remember by name for most part. I counted 16 deaths total in a hour and 40 mins, about a kill on average of 8.75 mins. Halloween fans will enjoy this new take. The theme is women facing their fears and overcoming their monsters that haunt their past. Jamie Lee Curtis performance was excellent, no cash grab role. The supporting cast and the shapes victims were also memorable. This is the perfect movie with Halloween just around the corner. I'd recommend horror fans or  anyone who wants a good story about women who face the boogeyman. 8/10 total for my rating. I rate the original slightly higher with 9/10.

Well the film is colorful and well lit but that is about it. Stupid characters all deserving the fates they suffer. 78% as of Sunday night, only proves people have lowered their standards. KILL THIS FRANCHISE!
Absolutely the best Halloween since the Original. This movie is the definition of a slasher movie and will keep you on the edge of your seat.

Well, well. Michael Myers is back at it again for the 10th time, and it's a huge relief that the Halloween series finally has another good movie. Seriously, this is a titanic step up from all the other ones, except maybe the original. Michael Myers feels like an actual threat again, and not some stupid cheesy slasher. Despite not saying a single word throughout the entire movie, he feels like a person. All the while, though, there were just some kills that were so unbelievably cheesy that it takes you right out of the movie, and this is especially hurtful to the movie because he original was so subtle with its kills. For the most part, though, it feel realistic enough to be somewhat possible, something important in horror. 

As to be expected in a modern horror, there is a hefty helping of fake-out scares. While not being so obnoxious that they make you want to vomit, (cough cough Conjuring series cough cough) they're still kinda irritating. But to compensate for the fake-outs, there's an awesome long take that follows Micheal as he resumes his killing spree in Haddonfield, and it feels just like the opening of the original. It really did put a smile on my face. Speaking of "just like he original," it's easy to tell that there was a lot of care put into making this one feel like the original, even down to the opening credits with the jack-o-lantern. 

The acting is a mixed bag. In the first act, the acting for Laurie's daughter is super wooden, and there are some other performances that don't quite feel real. However, Jamie Lee Curtis is amazing, and she feels like someone who was traumatized, and is desperately trying to cope with the horrors of her past. 

In short, Halloween is a love letter to the original, with some Blumhouse campiness included. It's giod, for certain, but just a few steps short from great.

I will begin by saying that I don't like horror movies. I scare easy and I hate getting scared in a theater full of people  who will probably laugh at my uncontrollable shrieking. However, my neuroses aside, I went to see the new Halloween film last night with a date who was proud to be a HUGE horror movie nerd. 

This film is made to be a direct sequel to the original 1978 film. we are made to believe that after Michael disappeared after falling out of a second foot window, he was arrested and sent to an insane asylum for the next 40 years. During that time the shrinks still couldn't crack what's inside the man's head so they gave up and get ready to ship him off to the local prison to spend the rest of his days.  But not before a couple of annoying European podcasters  seem to reawaken Michael's bloodlust during an interview in the rec yard (A creepy scene, especially in broad daylight).

On the outside world, Laurie Strode (Jamie Lee Curtis) has spent the past 40 years training for a future showdown with the serial killer, ruining her relationship with her daughter in the process but also fostering a good relationship with her grand daughter. 

Sure enough, the bus transferring Michael to prison gets into an accident and he's free to wreck havoc, releasing a second act full of clever and gruesome murder. 

I enjoyed the film. there were cheap jump scares and the classic horror tropes that made the original Halloween a classic. This film adds nothing new to the lore but happily strips all of the lore that has attached itself to the franchise in the past 40 years. This kind of bare bones horror slasher movie works better because there are fewer rules to follow. With that being said, I have no idea why Michael wants to kill Laurie or her family so bad. 

I'm sure someone will write about the theme of multi-generational  feminism that runs through the film (that would be an interesting essay). Someone else may also write about the racial stereotypes of white people in horror films  (which this film almost makes a statement about). The film is also heavy handed when it comes to the nostalgia factor of the film (John Carpenter's revisiting of his original score is amazing). But this film works best if you come to the theater looking to get a fright and see some bloody killings. 

My date, the hardcore horror nerd, was covering her eyes and grabbing my arm throughout the movie. So that must be a good sign.

We saw the new Halloween Movie last night!!! It was AMAZING! It's definately the next best Halloween movie no competition, and if it weren't for the classic status of the original it may even be the best quality wise. It has that Halloween John Carpenter feel, it's such a halloween movie in all the ways. Probably the best follow up to the first one. Soundtrack is great, characters are great, story is great, honestly I was just geeking out the whole time. Somehow feels classic and fresh at the same time Good fun Halloweeney scares too. HIGHLY RECOMENDED!

I'm glad I wrote this review after the initial high went down for me. I was exceptionally excited after first seeing it, the beginning credits brought a lot of nostalgia. The soundtrack was definitely a John Carpenter soundtrack. There were so many parallel scenes to the original movie. It really did the original justice. The acting was great by the main three girls as well. However, the comedy in this was terrible and useless. The original had such an eerie vibe, even in the down scenes of the original there was always some creepy background music playing and it really paced itself and made the whole experience more scary and have the fear stick longer. This one, whenever there wasn't a scary scene (and even during some scary scenes) that had to add these useless one liners. It was ridiculous and not everyone likes the toxic comedy genre to take over their genre. Stupid one liners have ruined so many modern movies for me, and this one isn't an exception. It appeals to the lowest common denominator of people, but I guess those are the ones giving movies the most money. While Jamie Lee Curtis killed her role, it was pointless to have her so obsessed with Michael after one night, 40 years ago. At least when he was her brother it made sense that she always felt the connection to him in H20. And even in H20 she wasn't as obsessed. It really didn't make sense. There were also a lot of cliche's in this movie. The pace was also just too fast. The original Halloween offered a stalking pace, Michael really followed and scared his prey. Here, he just killed whoever was around. I really wanted to love this movie, I was so excited. I still think it was good, but it was mainly the pointless comedy that ruined it for me. I hope the one liner fad starts to die off, but as long as people continue to stupidly fall for it, it'll be here for awhile.

So good.  Everything I wanted it to be and more.  Well written, well cast, well executed, great soundtrack & sound effects, scary, fun, and respectful of the original iconic characters.  The new Star Wars trilogy could learn a thing or two from this film.

Excellent I've seen all of them including this one was great too! Although he didnt die in the end there Totally making another one at some point.
Just AWESOME, none of those predictable jumpscares this can actually be called a Scary Movie

Best Halloween since the original, seriously a top notch sequel and a worthy one. You can tell David Gordon Green, Danny McBride and everyone involved really care about this franchise and about the fans. Laurie was so badass and I grew to love her even more & Michael was terrifying as fuck, the shape, a evil force of nature once again. I love how we see what effects this act of violence has had on the characters, which makes it more realistic and all the more terrifying.

This movie sucks viewers in the way the 1978 film did. Laurie, now a grandmother, has been waiting for Myers return for 40 Years, why? So she can kill him. Unlike last time she is prepared & ready for him, however she's still clearly still terrified when she comes face to face to him. 

In my opinion this brought back the terror of Michael that up until now, only the 1978 had. The movie doesn't try to be anything it's not and isn't afraid of dragging out the suspense whilst Myers stalks and eventually kills his victims. 

Furthermore you feel deeply for Laurie and she is as fully fledged out a  character as the horror genre allows for. By the end of the film you actually care for her and pray she doesn't get ambushed as she shakily searches for Michael in her home during the final act. 

If I had one complain to make, it would be that the ending scene was too abrupt & I would've liked to have seen a better ending.
Really poor. Boring build up and hardly any heart racing suspense.

The sequel to John Carpenter's classic is a return to form bringing in a nostalgic feel in it's storytelling, setup and tension without ripping off the original like modern remakes or sequels today. Not overly gratuitous in its violence this film feels accessible to those not looking for over the top gruesomeness but instead doubles down with increased tension, anticipation, and rawness of its kills. Jaime Lee Curtis plays her part perfectly, as a strong willed heroine, devoted to protecting her family, and hardened by the traumatizing experiences of her past. Although the movie was enjoyable, it was also balanced in its disappointment. Despite the film being rated R, the kills were mostly bland, usually taking place off screen while others simply tail ending carefully constructed tension and anticipation with a lackluster stab or neck snap. I feel that the movie's R rating was wasted and completely unnecessary and with very few modifications could have been a more widely accessible PG-13. Several of the characters, including Jamie Lee Curtis' character make clumsy usually disastrous decisions that go completely against character arc and development with some very confusingly nonsensical and out of no where twists. It is a sad fact to say that the only creativity of the kills didn't come from the kills themselves, instead from the display of the bodies afterwords which sums up the film as a whole, it's a mostly bland movie, with some very creative concepts; but a lot wasted opportunities and potential.

As far as sequels go, it's better than Rob Zombie's Halloween 2, but worse than the 1981 Halloween 2. With a lot of moments that seemed badly placed, this film gives the Halloween franchise the The Force Awakens treatment, and I didn't appreciate it when they did it to Star Wars. Taking all it's positives from the original, and failing with most of the new parts, the film seems like a jumbled mess that combines the original Halloween with Halloween 6, Halloween H20 and Home Alone, and fails to capture anything other than the disappointment that came from seeing Halloween 6. Forgetting parts of the plot and going overboard on the "Final girl" trope, the film feels like exactly what it is: a horror fan trying to do the job of a horror professional.

I am a huge Halloween fan so the excitement I had to see this movie can't even be fully described! I finally went to see it and walked out of the theater completely disappointed. The intro was lacking to say the least. I felt disinterested in anything that was happening. This movie is extremely slow burning and ends before it even achieves any major spark. I feel as though this whole movie was rushed to be made and ended up being a nothing but a huge mess. There were so many unnecessary scenes, poor acting at times, and it was a serious struggle to keep my eyes open. There are so many reviews stating how this movie was so BRUTAL....truthfully they must not watch many horror type movies then because the only way I could use "brutal" when describing this movie is to say it was BRUTALLY AWFUL! On an upside, Jamie Lee Curtis did a fantastic job acting but the plot made her fall short. I agree that Michael doesn't need a backstory but I feel like having him and her be brother and sister gave the movies that extra scare factor. Since they took that part out of this movie, it made it seem dull. The kills are mediocre at best. It drags on so much that you feel like the movie is 3 hours long. The ending was rushed and lacked any type of thrill. If you are hoping for an "edge of your seat" type movie, I suggest staying home and finding something else to watch because you won't receive that from this.

Overall I thought this movie was pretty dang good. There have been a few criticisms, some which are valid and some which are subjective.  There are a few plot holes that never get filled, so that's a strike against this movie, but I think most movies have similar issues if examined closely enough. Some of the other problems people have, such as the humor, completely depends on your opinion. Personally I liked the humor for the most part - it made the movie feel more realistic. It's not the goriest Halloween, and I appreciate that, but I feel it's the sequel that shows the most respect to Micheal Myers. There's no unnecessary backstory for him, no weird supernatural stuff, just Micheal lumbering around and killing people for no reason, which is what Micheal does.  The characters aren't all super fleshed out, but they are mostly likeable. The plot isn't great, but it's enough to get Micheal out and about again, which is really what you're watching this movie for in the first place anyways. Jamie Lee Curtis was great in my opinion as Laurie Strode. The best thing this movie could have done is exactly what it did, and that's ignore all of the other Halloween films except for the first one. It makes sense and isn't crazy and convoluted like some of the sequels. 

My biggest issue with the movie is probably a common one, and that's with a certain plot twist about halfway through the movie that really comes out of nowhere and doesn't make a lot of sense. This movie would have been phenomenal if they had left that out entirely, but it's in there, and the movie overall is worse off for it in my opinion. Word on the street is that there's a Director's cut of this movie that will be released, and I can only hope that they pull that twist out. 

The ending was underwhelming in my opinion, but not for lack of trying. They certainly wanted the movie to end with a bang, which it did, but not a kind of impactful bang. Overall I liked the movie - it's my favorite Halloween sequel by a long shot, mostly just because I don't have to think about all of the weird crap from the other ones. I think casual fans of the series such as myself will enjoy it, and I recommend buying a ticket to watch it in theaters. Watching Micheal Myers return to killing after 40 patient years is fun, even with the flaws.

Halloween (2018) was the sequel that Halloween (1978) always deserved. This movie, from the beginning preys on those who have watched to original. There is occasional fan service with paralleled scenes from the original and occasional nods to the terribly convoluted story that the original sequels tried to make, but none of it comes off hamfisted. The movie is terrifying in every aspect and still manages to squeeze in some genuinely hilarious dialogue. This is also helped by a killer cast of actors who can really sell the concept of the Boogeyman. This movie lives up to the hype in every imaginable way and don't believe anyone that tells you otherwise. Pure evil has come back to Haddonfield and his name is Michael.

Halloween 2018 is a triumphant return to form for the Halloween franchise, and a signal for a new era of horror reboots, one that hopefully brings more to the table than the Michael Bay driven era of remakes from the early 2000s. Jamie Lee Curtis once again returns to her most iconic role of Laurie Strode, horror's ultimate final girl, for one last battle against her nemesis Michael Myers. Joining in on the fight is a whole family of Strodes, including Karen Strode played by Judy Greer, and newcomer Andi Matichak playing Allyson Strode. The three generations of Strode women band together in a fiery climax to rid Haddonfield of it's dreaded boogeyman once and for all. 

Behind the scenes we have franchise creator John Carpenter returning after a long hiatus away from the series, this time as an executive producer and of course, also composing a new and soon to be iconic score. Malek Akkad, son of series grandfather Moustapha Akkad, now leads the series, and franchise newcomers David Gordon Green and Danny McBride join the series as director and screenwriter respectively, along with Jeff Fadley. Jason Blum also produces as apart of his studio Blumhouse, which is currently dominating the horror genre alongside Warner Bros, and we couldn't be happier about that. Horror has undergone a renaissance in the last few years. So many quality horror films and reboot are being made, and there is so much money being brought into the box office. We are all so lucky as movie and horror fans to be living in this era. I'm excited what we're gonna see next, in terms of both the Halloween franchise and horror in general. 

As always, I'll start with what I did like first.

The acting and performances were all top notch. Jamie Lee Curtis brings her all to this role. When she passes away, it'll be this role and her work in horror that she'll be most remembered for I believe, and with performances like this, it's not hard to see why. There's a sincere grief and trauma that haunts Laurie all throughout the film. I could see the fear and pain in her eyes from everything she suffered all those years ago, and her interactions with her family were the most heartfelt and sincere moments I've ever seen in this series. Curtis also shines on the opposite side of that spectrum and kicks plenty of ass in the film as well. Her compound was full of Home Alone style booby traps and there were many moments of the film were Laurie mimicked Michael from the original Halloween, which I thought was insanely clever and the best kind of referencing and fan service. The other members of the cast were also all good. I especially liked Judy Greer as Laurie's long suffering daughter Karen. She had a lot of surprising moments, and her backstory felt natural and real. She also had probably the most badass moment of the film, when she pretends to be scared and cries out for her mom, and when Michael takes the bait and appears in front of her, she quickly snaps back and shoots him straight to the ground. Bad-fucking-ass. That's exactly the kind of character development I want to see in my slasher films. Andi Matichak was good as well. I thought a lot of the scenes of her and her friends were nice updated versions of the scenes with Laurie and her friends from the original film. Some of her friends were a little obnoxious and I could have done without them, but overall her character and interactions with her family and friends were a nice diversion away from the dark and brutal killings. I think the best teen characters were definitely Miles Robbins and Virginia Gardner. Gardner especially had a really good scene when she was babysitting, and the back and forth between her and the child she was watching was nice and sweet, as well as hilarious as hell. The entire theatre was cracking up during these scenes. Nick Castle and James Courtney share the role of Michael Myers, and it was refreshing to see to original Shape back in action. I felt the detachment, the evil, his pure menace as he stalked to streets of Haddonfield and racked up an impressive body count. As a whole, most of the characters were charming and likeable, something you can't say for many of the other Halloween sequels or slasher films in general. Many of the deaths were hard to watch because I genuinely didn't want the characters to die. GOOD SCREENWRITING! It's kinda important

The directing and cinematography were the best since the original film. David Gordon Green made this movie his own, and didn't just rehash the same scenes over and over again. He paid tribute to the entire series in a clever and respectful way, which was smart considering many fans were upset about the ignoring of all the sequels. Those long tracking shots and the many shots of Michael lurking in the background and behind people were the true essence of Halloween. I was skeptical of Green's ability to helm one of horror's most iconic characters, but he succeeded in spectacular fashion.

I can't think of another horror series where the music is just as much a character as the actual characters in the movie, and the music here is simply superb, and it's even more incredible that it's provided by the man himself John Carpenter. Where do I even begin with Carpenter. He's the man. His filmography is so vast and he's created so many modern classics it's ridiculous. And he's scored almost all of his own films, with Halloween 2018 being the first film he's composed the music for that he didn't write or direct. The new themes, especially the one used for Allyson's chase scene. I liked the new variations of the classic score, and the ending credit theme is probably my favorite track of the score. 

The choice to ignore all the previous sequels was the right one in my opinion. There are many fans out there that wished Halloween II had been included in the canon, but wiping the slate completely clean and just using the original film as a jumping off point makes so much sense. The continuity of the Halloween franchise is almost singularly unique amongst horror series. There are so many timelines and resets that trying to find a way to make a true sequel to this series is near impossible. So it makes sense to just go back to the original 1978 film and build a story from there. It provides us with a much better version of the story Halloween H20 tried to tell, and wasn't entirely successful in doing. We get a psychologically damaged Laurie who has pushed everyone away from her, two generations of Strodes that have been touched by Michael Myers in different ways, and we get the best motivation for Michael to hunt Laurie; she's the "one who got away". That to me is miles better than having them be brother and sister. It makes Michael scary again, and his pursuit of Laurie more interesting. The way the film narratively and cinematically links the film to the 1978 Halloween is so much more effective than the dozens of homages the series has paid to the original film, and makes for a more seamless transition between the two films. There were so many moments that mirrored or referenced the original, but in a unique way that I loved. It completely subverted my expectations time and time again, and it's been so long since a Halloween movie, or any horror movie, has done that. 

This Halloween is relentless and brutal in the best way possible. Michael Myers truly is The Shape again, and the embodiment of pure evil that John Carpenter and Debra Hill intended him to be all those years ago. That long tracking shot of Michael going from house to house and randomly murdering people was the perfect image of what Michael Myers is supposed to be. Pure, unfiltered rage and evil. And I also respect horror movies that have the courage to place small children in mortal danger. The Halloween series has a history of this, and it's nice to see it return once again. 

This was the first Halloween film since Halloween 6 that had a Halloween atmosphere. Some people already disagree with me, but the choice to film in the winter was a great choice, and the background and fall decorations all gave the film a nice crisp autumn vibe. 

I liked that the original credits and fonts from the first movie were used. It was another bit of connective tissue that connected it with the original Halloween. Being such a young fan, I haven't seen a quality Halloween film in theatres, and seeing the font and iconic titles on screen felt like watching the original film back in 1978

Things I didn't like

The opening credits rubbed me the wrong for some reason. I didn't like the inflating pumpkin, even though I get the concept behind it. It looked to fake in my opinion, and the titles went by too fast. 

Some of the humor was misplaced, and deflated some of the tension of the movie. The babysitter murder scene was a prime example, as the young child who was being babysat was making jokes during his babysitter's actual murder and it did not gel with the rest of the scene. Some of the other scenes with Allyson's friends were a tab bit off putting, and I would have preferred more scenes with the Strodes.

The podcasters didn't really add anything new or that interesting to the film. The two actors did a great job, and their opening scene was nice, with them meeting Michael at Smith's Grove, but their storyline never really panned out the way I wanted. I was expecting them to provide a commentary on how culture's fascination with serial killers, and while there was some of that in flashes, especially the cemetary scene, there wasn't enough to justify their inclusion in the film, and they ultimately only serve as a means for Michael to get his mask back. I wish they had more meaningful scenes before being violently murdered.

This is not a slight on the movie itself, but more of the series as a whole. Because Halloween has hit the reset button so many times, there's a sense familiarity to the proceedings. This isn't the first time Laurie and Michael have faced off against each so many years after the original, and the film loses some of its impact because of that. Several scenes also felt too similar to the other films, and so the film didn't feel as fresh as it could have been. Once again, nothing against the movie itself, but it being the 11th film in the series weakens some of its bite.

Final thoughts

Perhaps no movie or sequel in the Halloween franchise will ever come close to topping John Carpenter's immortal classic, but Halloween 2018 comes mighty close. The story, performances, direction, and atmosphere are supremely ahead of anything this franchise has attempted before. I was blown away by the commitment by everyone involved with this project, and the film met my very low expectations and then some. It's far from a perfect movie, but very few movies are. The original Halloween itself wasn't an immediate classic,  and I believe with time, this one may be seen as being worthy of that 1978 film by all audiences. The filmmakers held such a deep reverence for the Halloween franchise, and respected it and its fans, and that's why the film works on so many levels. I haven't seen a horror sequel/reboot made with this much respect and effort in quite some time, and the levels of success an box office the film is already achieving warms my heart. I hope this is a signal to a new wave of quality horror reboots. After the last wave left such a bad taste in the mouths of so many fans and movie goers, it's time our favorite slasher/horror icons get a second chance to reinvent themselves. And we should all be so lucky if they come halfway to matching David Gordon Green's Halloween.

Speaking only as someone who's seen mere parts of the first installment, I understand that my opinion on this eleventh entry may be a bit lacking in value or context, but my honest impression still stands; I thought this was a fantastic time. A really great, post-modern premise fits snugly beside the solid atmosphere and air established by the methodical directorial stylings of David Gordon Green. The added benefit of having to witness one of Jamie Lee Curtis's best performances is also something of tremendous note. Overall, I had a blast watching "Halloween," and I hope this acts as a wakeup call to many other studio execs looking to cash in on nostalgic brand names. When the trailer for Halloween 2018 played before our eyes, we felt excited that Michael Myers was going to return in full bloody glory. However, while this film has its moments of tension and nostalgia, there are many points where the horror falls short and Jamie Lee Curtis' returning character, Laurie Strode, is sadly underused. Disregarding all the Halloween sequels that came before this movie was conceived, this 2018 film reboot of Halloween picks up 40 years after the events of the 1978 John Carpenter classic. Laurie Strode is now an old woman who has an estranged relationship with her daughter and lives in isolation from the rest of the neighborhood. Michael Myers is imprisoned in a psychiatric hospital, despondent and still as a statue. The film opens with two investigative journalists trying to write a piece on the events of Michael Myers' killing spree 40 years. They are clearly obsessed with his infamy, going so far as to track down Laurie Strode and get her perspective on the events; she didn't bite though.
	Michael Myers escapes because of a prison bus transfer gone wrong in the middle of nowhere. He effectively kills any witnesses, retrieves his familiar mask (after violently disposing of the previous owners), and goes to his neighborhood of potential victims. Presumably, his goal is to murder Laurie Strode and her offspring, killing any other humans along the way. This is more or less what we expect from a Halloween film, however, what would have made the film more fascinating is if it delved into the tortured psyche of Laurie Strode. Before Michael's escape, Laurie Strode appears as a crazy old lady stuck in her paranoid way which is the reason why her daughter Karen keeps herself and her family distant. Karen's daughter, Allyson, is a teenager who wonders why her grandmother is still obsessed with Michael after all these decades, but other than that she does normal teenager things like go to the Halloween dance and, later loses her cool when Myers begin his murder spree.     
This is actually one of the biggest problems with the film. It never really feels like a Halloween film, instead opting for a DJ style scratch and match of different pieces from each of the films in the franchise, even borrowing kills from the horror genre a large. There is a scene near the beginning of the film which perfectly highlights a lot of the problems the film has. In this scene, the family has been trying to coax the traumatized matriarch of the family out of her hiding all and into a Formica diner of sorts. The dialogue between the various people at the table is cut more like a fight scene than a plot device. The cutting is jumpy, sporadic, it lacks rhythm and most of all, it needlessly builds and discards tension without a payoff; one of the cardinal sins a form of the storytelling. The primary problem of the film is that whoever was its biggest mastermind has no sense of mood or tone.
We don't want to come off as though we didn't enjoy the film at all, quite to the contrary this is a very good Friday night Halloween rental. But it doesn't feel like an entry into the franchise that we have all waited so long to see a proper sequel to. Friends the franchise will no doubt be frustrated by the lack of innovation. We do, however, find that perhaps maybe younger viewers less familiar with the franchise will find it to be an exciting and funny addition to their horror movie repertoire. After all, we do spend countless scenes following Jamie Lee Curtis's granddaughter instead of developing any plot, it is a thread that is dropped cold without explanation, without connection to the other entries into the franchise. If you're looking for a movie that is worthy of the title, I guess we'll have to wait for another generation of filmmakers. With that being said, if you are looking for a pretty good slasher movie to pass the weekend with, this is where we think the movie fits best.  To sum it all up this movie (if it were a costume), would be perfect for the kid that loves to scare the crap out of people who has no idea who he wants to be. For the kid that wanted to be Michael Myers though, it's like getting a Frankenstein mask because it's all they had left.

Incredible film. We just saw Halloween and let me tell you, it didn't disappoint. A fantastic production made for Halloween fans by Halloween fans so-to-speak. The attention to detail, the homages paid to the past with spoken: "that's the idea", and seen: a familiar sun hat on Laurie's wall. A brilliant mask, and Jamie Lee Curtis' performance all make this instant Classic a must see. In this Halloween some 40 years later, we find Michael Myers more vicious and extremely brutal in his killing methods. Also the depth of Curtis' character Laurie Strode can't be overstated. The PTSD that she's endured since 1978, how the experience has taken hold of her life, the failed marriage's and estrangement from her daughter, have all added new dimensions to this now mentally toughened character. If I had to sum this movie up in one word, it would be "spooky". To briefly name a few scenes which I found exceptionally chilling, they would be the scene at Smith's Grove, a handful of teeth in a gas station restroom, the reflection in the window, a teenager and some motion lights, Dr. Sartain's complete 180, and Michael's special jack-o'-lantern. The film had some comedic elements as well, particularly Jibrail Nantambu who played Julian. If there was ever a scene stealer in a Slasher film, he was it. His appearance was only brief, however very memorable with his one-liners and overall humor. With this being said, Halloween is a solid movie from beginning to end, and be sure to stay for the end credits to hear one of Laurie's favorite tunes from years past by.

Despite the promise of the trailer the movie itself turned out very average. There was some bad acting with tertiary characters (In a horror? Who'd have thought!) and an odd number of laughs thrown in that didn't seem to fit, there are also one completely unneccisary plot twist that added nothing to the story. None of those were as big an issue as the fact I didn't feel they did Michael justice. They toned down his supernatural side to make him seem more human (always a mistake) and his kills reminded me more of Jason Voorheese's style than his own. Lacking was the disturbing curiousity he used to show around his victims and he did very little in the way of toy them (like when he wore the sheet to pretend to be a ghost in the original). Michael also managed very little in the way of stalking.

Jamie Lee was superb (and I'd expect nothing less) and this is really Laurie's story not Michaels. Unfortunately this is also her fifth Halloween with three of her appearances being retconned by this movie, this somewhat reduces the impact of her story as we've seen different versions of it several times over. Also on the positive side was the superb soundtrack provided by John Carpenter and his son which helped to give the movie a bit more of an authentic feel. As is often the case the references to the original movie were blatantly and didn't really add anything. 

Final note, this a replacement to Halloween 2 and it's suprisingly similar to that movie. Which ultimately leaves me wondering what the point was in taking this route. We now have three branching continuities of Halloween and that's not even taking in to account the Rob Zombie remake. Did we really need that?
