Paying great respect to the original Halloween and franchise as a whole, Halloween (2018) delivers Michael Myers true, absolute self with suspense, horrific kills, extreme body count, and a showdown with his true adversary: the badass heroine, Laurie Strode. It wisely ignores all Halloween timelines and projects as a direct sequel to the original. Forever haunted by her encounter with Michael Myers 40 years ago, Laurie Strode has spent her life preparing herself and her family for the inevitable escape of 'The Shape' and his long pending return to Haddonfield, IL. After being apprehended in 1978 following the babysitter murders, he has spent the last 40 years locked up back in Smith's Grove with his doctor's, and the state ignoring Dr. Loomis's long ago given, strong recommendation that he should be executed. He is scheduled to be transferred from Smith's Grove, which during the transfer, he escapes custody and can return to the one thing he's only loved: killing and the white mask. Director and writer David Gordon Green gives the audience no insight into Michael's motivations for why he does the things he does, or why he seemingly won't die. The only shred of theory is given by his doctor, the protege of Dr. Loomis. He achieves in keeping the character of Michael Myers ambigiously absolute. Laurie Strode is all but excommunicated by her daughter and son-in-law for refusing to get the help she needs and make peace with her attempted murder 40 years ago. Her granddaughter is the only family member who wants her around and thinks she should be given a chance. Finally, Laurie's fears come to fruition and the family is forced to confront them together. Subjectively speaking, the film does a good job at capturing the essence of Michael except for his stalkerish ways. Where it slightly lacks in living up to the original is having scenes that are from Michael's perspective where in the original, it is told completely by Michael's prey and victims. Filled with suspense, jumps, brutal kills, comic relief and intelligent writing, it makes for a great horror film and solid addition to the Halloween franchise. Debra Hill I think would be most proud of the handling of her story and characters. A must scream for horror fans. Welcome home, Michael and Laurie.

Let me start with the positives, because there are quite a few. Firstly, the performances were great all across the board. There really wasn't a single member of the cast that didn't give it their all. Jamie Lee Curtis, especially. She's just phenomenal in this film. Her portrayal of the effects of trauma on someone's mental state was perfect. All the scenes with her were golden. Judy Greer as Laurie's daughter, Karen, does a great job, as does Andi Matichak, who plays Laurie's granddaughter, Allyson. All in all, great work from the cast. They all turned in great performances.

Michael Myers is scarier in this movie than he has ever been. Michael has always been a symbol of pure evil, and this movie does its very best to drive that home. The things he does in this movie are horrific and terrifying, and that's exactly the way it should be. I have to give credit to Danny McBride and his co-writers for nailing that aspect of the character. He is a force of pure evil and does not care about anyone or anything. This movie got that right, and I commend it.

One final positive to note is the direction. David Gordon Green does a beautiful job directing this movie. It feels like Halloween in this movie. The falling leaves, the jack o' lanterns, etc. There are a couple long takes in the middle of the film that are very impressive. Also, there's a clever thing that Green does in which he copies trademark shots from the original film while putting a specific twist on them. I thought that that was a really smart way to relate the themes of the film symbolically and visually. The cinematography was good too. It was a beautiful film to look at.

Now, the negatives.

This movie completely fell apart at the beginning of the 3rd act. I won't spoil it, but a certain character does something that comes completely out of left field and is just mind boggling. The moment it happened, I turned to my brother and said, "Dude, this is stupid." After this completely random and bizarre event occurs (Which by the way, has absolutely no effect on the plot) the rest of the film takes a nose dive. The climax is okay in certain moments, but overall very disappointing. There's a pretty suspenseful scene that takes place in Laurie's home, but otherwise, it was really mediocre; verging on bad.

Also, there were many instances of comedic relief that came at wildly inappropriate times. There is a child in this film that someone is babysitting and he exists solely as comedic relief. He literally comes into contact with Michael and the scene is played for laughs. There are also other scenes of random comedy scattered throughout, so it makes the film feel very tonally jarring a lot of the time. We go from being terrified at this force of evil, to laughing at the fact that a certain character packed a single brownie into his lunch. There was very little tonal consistency, especially in the last half. It reminded me of the Last Jedi in that way. *shutters*

Overall, the new Halloween was fantastic for the first hour or so, but as soon as the 3rd act began, it just got worse and worse. Had the 3rd act been just as good as what came before, this movie would have been a solid 8 or 9, topping all the other sequels. However, because of just how disappointing the finale of the movie is, and the tonal inconsistency, I can't give it a score that high. It's better than many of the sequels, but I think the original 1981 Halloween II still has it beat. There were great moments in this movie. A lot of them. It's really a shame.

Michael Myers has been waiting for this night to escape (again). He's being transferred to another prison (again). He's going to steal a car (again). He's going to walk among trick or treaters and kill random people in their house (again). He's going to go after Laurie Strode (again). 

Pros
-The mask looks great.
-This movie proves that you can't catch lightening in a bottle twice.
-This movie proves Halloween is nothing without Donald Pleasence. 

Cons
-It's all hype.
-It does not meet expectations if you're a fan.
-The movie feels unfinished. 
-Brings nothing new to the table. 
-There was nothing original.
-Felt like a cash grab. 
-Wasn't scary.
-Rehashes the same plot from the first one: He escapes, gets the car......
-British podcasters were a waste of time.
-Laurie's daughter and granddaughter are unlikable.
-They don't show how Michael survived getting shot by Loomis and falling from the balcony. The coolest ending is horror history and they don't acknowledge it. 
-They don't show how they captured Michael.

Final Thoughts:
I watch Halloween every October. And I've been doing that for 25 years. The new Halloween is a major let down. Part 2 and part 4 were better than this. 
Hell, I was more excited about the Happy Death Day 2U trailer that was before this.

Killer Mike is back...Michael Myers that is. Halloween (2018) is one of the best horror films I've seen in a while. It keeps the spirit of John Carpenter's original film and it feels as if Carpenter could have even directed some scenes. The 80s style synth music is a great old school sounding score with a modern take. At first, I felt bad for Laurie Strode (Jamie Lee Curtis) and what her later life has become. But she proves she is still tougher than ever. Even though it is a direct sequel to the original, it has references to the other previous movies. It does have some horror cliches we've seen so many times, but horror-heads will love it. Also, even though it's putting the previous movies aside and only focusing on the original, it still sort of plays out like those other sequels only ignoring Halloween: Resurrection. In other words, maybe they didn't have to ignore all the sequels. The film has amazing tension, it captures the spirit of the holiday, it feels like it fits with the original, and Myers is still eerie in every way possible. As a long time fan of the "Halloween" franchise I was intrigued when I learned that Horror Master John Carpenter would be taking a hands on role in the latest installment of the fabled saga that Carpenter himself unleashed onto the world way back in 1978. In fact, this was the first Michael Myers Halloween film that Carpenter had been involved with since Halloween II in 1981. I was even more intrigued to learn that this latest installment would completely disavow the storylines from every other Halloween film that came AFTER the original 1978 classic. If that wasn't enough, it would be divulged in one of the first official trailers of the new film that Michael Myers, aka "The Boogieman" and Laurie Strode, the survivor of the first stab fest in 1978, ARE NOT BROTHER AND SISTER. For fans of the series, it was revealed in the 1981 sequel, "Halloween II" that Myers and Strode were siblings and that he wanted to kill Laurie, much like he killed his other sister, Judith Myers when he was 6 years old, which was documented during the opening scenes of the 1978 original film. So, we are left to wonder, why is Michael Myers so hell bent on finally killing Laurie Strode after all of these years. Well, when you see this latest installment you would be hard pressed to get any clarity to that answer. So, this film is really another redux of a sequel to the original 1978 film fast forward 40 years. So, instead of Michael getting up after being shot six times by Michael's psychiatrist and falling off the balcony of Tommy Doyle's house only to continue the nights rampage in the 1981 sequel, Michael is apprehended and is incarcerated at a state mental hospital where he has remained for the last 40 years. As far as Laurie Strode goes, again played by original scream queen Jamie Lee Curtis, the last 40 years have not been kind to her. During this film, the audience learns that she has been married and divorced twice, she has 2 kids, one of which, her daughter, was taken from her custody when the girl was 12 years old. She also spent the last 40 years living in constant fear and paranoia and also preparing and praying that Michael would escape custody and, once again, come after her. Her back woods home was basically a fortress built on the fear that Michael would come after her again, decked out with security cameras, flood lights and enough weapons for a small army. But without giving away too much of the plot, what I really enjoyed about this movie was that it did pay homage to the films that came before it even if those storylines were basically erased from history. When I say paying homage to the other films I'm referring to that several of the scenes of this film were framed to look like or resemble scenes from the previous films, which fans of the series will know what I am talking about. But at the end of the day, this was a pretty good horror movie that resembled and had the traits of its 1978 predecessor, genuine scares without getting too bogged down on trying to figure out what made Michael ticked. Just like the original film, this installment still really didn't divulge why Michael is obsessed with Laurie and that makes Michael that much more dangerous and that much more frightening, to wonder what set Michael off and why, after 40 years, why he still had an unquenchable thirst and desire to kill, and to keep on killing, of which, me may never know the answer to.

Halloween is a success from a cinematography and audio-visual standpoint, but a monumental failure in plot and character progression, logic, pacing, and feels closer to the Rob Zombie reboots than the Carpenter classic from 1978. 

Perhaps this is due to the sheer brutality of the kills this time around, the unrelenting force of evil that is Michael myers is on a rampage seldom seen in prior movies. the body count is high, the gore is off the charts and this works to undercut something the original had in spades - the foreboding sense of dread and atmosphere. 

We see 'the shape' far too much on-screen, the stalking has been toned down to this films' detriment, and for some reason the breathing of Myers reminded me a lot of Darth vader to the point where it was off-putting.

The new Dr. Loomis character is by far the worst inclusion in the film and his wacky motivations for Michael revealed in the third act are laughable at best.

This is my first review here on RT, so here is my non-spoiler quick review of HALLOWEEN 2018... It's super violent. Don't go into this movie expecting to see your standard run-of-the-mill horror film. I have seen practically every horror movie on the planet and I can honestly say this movie felt disturbing on many levels throughout the film. You actually care about the people dying and feel horrified for them. That being said, if you can get past the large kill count and violence, GO SEE THIS MOVIE. It is the best sequel in the series without a doubt and is a solid movie in general. Jamie Lee Curtis and the rest of the cast portray believable characters and the cast direction is on mark. This is one of the first films I have ever seen that had my expectations up and did not disappoint. I absolutely loved it from start to finish. I also feel the need (not want...) to see this film again. It has so many amazing sights and settings are above standard for a horror film. Beautifully directed. They obviously took great care in doing this film. Again... 9 out of 10 knife slashes from me.

The story line flows well defines its characters with ease and it creates a realistic environment making the movie believable. There are no possessions or supernatural monsters in this, it's simply a psychotic murderer that does not stop. It brings back all of the old gruesome deaths that we all remember from the old one and takes it up another level. Simply put this will give slasher movies a bump that they need, just as the first one did. Jamie Lee Curtis was superb as to be expected she embodies her character making you feel sympathy for what she is going through along with giving you reason to root for her. Surprising the film dives into the workings of the inner mind in a way creating something different for you to process during the film. In the end, if you are a horror fan, old school slasher flick fan, or just a movie fan go see it in theaters and enjoy the ride.

Being able to maintain its suspense and horror while also being able to be a genuine piece of art and talk about serious social issues is a testament to their ability. I thought the original Halloween was one of the most well-made horror movies I’ve seen. What I admired most about is that scenes were as suspenseful and scary in broad daylight as they were at night, and the ability to produce a scare with very little gore until the end. Well, this movie saturates you with both gore and suspense, so if you don’t like gore, you better cover your eyes and your ears. Moving onto Laurie, who doesn’t love Jamie Lee Curtis? I had to see it to find out what happened to the poor girl. I do agree with another reviewer that there was little character development of the granddaughter and her mother. I was unimpressed with both of these characters. I LOVED the tributes given to the original movie. And the little kid who was being babysat is fantastic and he has a great future ahead of him as an actor! All in all, a fun movie at Halloween and I still worry that I will see his face in the mirror behind me.

This is an excellent movie! I wish I could give it five stars and call it a masterpiece. Alas, I cannot. The humor was inappropriate at times (horrible in one particular scene), the new psychologist was bordering on superfluous, and the British podcasters were not much more than a plot device. Those things being said, the movie is incredible. Jamie Lee Curtis turns in an astounding performance as Laurie Strode, who is both weaker and stronger after the terror of the original Halloween. Stronger--she is tough and has prepared herself for fighting Michael Myers for 40 years. And weaker--she suffers from PTSD and has allowed it to damage her familial relationships. Both sides are portrayed well--stellar performance! Judy Greer does excellently as Karen Strode. Virginia Gardner delivers a decent performance, as does the man who plays her father. The boys in the film seem like typical high school boys and serve their purpose, though one of the characters could have been more compelling. Michael Myers was menacing, unstoppable, and straightforward in his kills. The suspense in most of the scenes was pulled off masterfully. The Third Act was intense and dramatic -- genuine edge of your seat quality! This isn't a slasher flick devoted to murdering dumb, young hedonists that you feel indifferent about at best. No, you care about Laurie and her struggles, and this care is made all the more palpable in the Third Act. The soundtrack was beautiful and added tremendously to the suspense and ambience of the film. Love this movie. Will be buying it on Blu-Ray. 4/5 Stars

Tonally, Halloween is all over the place, seemingly determined to be a well-blended mix of slasher-fare, humor, and teenage drama/camp. Even if this may seem like a negative, it actually works well for the film, keeping the audience on its toes between all the carnage. Jamie Lee Curtis delivers a strong performance, conveying the ptsd attributed to her surviving all those years prior convincingly. And yet, when she had to throw down with demon from her past, she did just that and then some. One of the more effective aspects of the film is how Michael relentlessly stalks and kills his randomly picked victims. Unlike the sequels after Carpenter's original, Michael doesn't seem to be after anyone in particular. He just wants, or maybe even needs to kill. Halloween packs a mean punch and nobody is safe from Michaels swath of bloodshed. As for acting, Judy Greer is spectacular as Laurie's resentful and distant daughter. As the movie progressed, she transforms from emotionally hurt duckling to a likeable daughter/mother. Andi Matichak turns in a decent performance, bringing an emotional depth to her character that isn't ever fully developed. The male actors suffer the most in this film. Will Patton is the only male character that seems decent and even his way of handling Laurie is a bit red-flaggish. The high school guys all come off like jerks and they aren't developed to any point where it matters if they meet the blade or not. The pod cast crew is annoying and deliberately inappropriate, serving well the transition from the original film to the present one. All in all, a great film, even with a minor misstep that seems present solely to deliberately move the plot forward.

Michael Myers of the 2018 Halloween was spot on with the original which by itself, is a reason to see the film. There were a few cliche horror film antics that became annoying at times however the overall creepyness of the character was enough forget about any annoyances. It is refreshing to finally see John Carpenters original vision of a mortal man, not an invincible or magic monster, but a genuine mentally ill evil psychopath return in a sequel. What drew fans to the first film has been missed by every previous sequel, which is the site of Michael Myers while he is watching and pursuing. The act of grotesque killing is rarely what is scary or memorable. The most difficult part of any scary movie is often the ending and this version of Halloween is no exception, it didn't live up to the original although that might be the best ending to any horror film. I do hope there is another sequel carried by the same team that produced this one but there is definitely no certainty that it was intended.

Halloween (4 out of 5 stars). Halloween is back and plays it safe following after the original John Carpenter's film. Basically, starting a brand new fresh take on the franchise while forgetting all those sequels and Rob Zombie's reboot movies. All thanks to David Gordon Green and Danny McBride's fresh take on the sequel while paying a great follow up to the 1978 version. Jamie Lee Curtis is back and better than ever as Laurie Strode. Michael Myers new aged mask is creepy. And there are more body counts as Myer's cross paths with idiot teenagers, police officers, and more stand by victims. The plot follows right after the original movie. Decades later, after Myers is being held at an institution facility, waiting for transfer. Laurie Strode (Jamie Lee Curtis) is prepared for Michael's escape. As her house is a fortress with traps, weapons, cameras, and so much more. Laurie is trying to reconnect with her daughter Karen (Judy Greer) and her granddaughter Allyson (Andi Matichak). As the bus transfer crashes, Michael escapes. And is back on his killing spree. Laurie tries to gather her family to safety and plotting to kill Michael. I am sure it has a plot that has been done before with slasher films. McBride and David Green's script tries to add some freshness to it. The opening moments in the psych ward after two journalists want to speak to Myers. And the opening credits with John Carpenter's theme song brought back. The film sets up the setting with characters like Laurie's daughter and her granddaughter. While they fear that Laurie is still disturbed and needs help. While her paranoia is getting her prepared to face what is about to come. When Michael does escape, he is back on his killing spree. The kills are not as gory or bloody. Just quick deaths with the characters and maybe one or two aftermath disturbing scene with the dead bodies. The suspense build up does bring some chills. Especially on a scene were Michael walks into some random persons house to kill them with a hammer and walk out with a kitchen knife. The film does have that typical horror movie cliché with stupidity. Wish they could have left out and done something smarter with characters choices. Such as a teen girl slipping when being chased. Or characters letting Michael grab them without putting much of a fight back. But the film makes up for it in the last 20 minutes. When Michael and Laurie are facing against each other. As she is putting up a fight and trying to kill. Jamie Lee Curtis is great. Judy Greer and Andi Matichak are great. At least they did not make much bad decisions. Will Patton plays a police officer that is trying to stop Myers. Overall, Halloween is a good slasher film. It brings a fresh take on a dying franchise. Especially, when Rob Zombie ruined it. It feels like a true sequel after the original movie. There may not be gory deaths, or scary. But it does have its suspense. Jamie Lee Curtis shines along with new cast members like Judy Greer and Andi Matichak. I am excited to see were they can take another movie. Hope they can leave out the clichés of stupidity.

Michael Meyers was the thing I was most scared of growing up, other than the Unsolved Mysteries theme song.  I spent literal YEARS hiding under my blankets in Santa Cruz, completely afraid of The Shape, staying up all night fearful that I would one day hear that iconic breathing through the white mask.  I can still remember it to this day.  This movie continues the story of what I consider the scariest movie of all time.  The reason why I think Halloween (1978) is the all time greatest is simple: it's a basic story that "could" be wrapped in reality.  Nightmare on Elm Street, Friday the 13th, those are all based in fantasy worlds where unbelievable super-villains roam the world killing random horny teenagers.  Michael Myers was immediately given a back story (murders his sister and parents, locked up and escapes, etc.), which made his story rooted in REALITY.  To me, that was something that drove fear into my heart as a child.  This movie was an excellent continuation of the original story, with plenty of homages to the original script.  Jamie Lee Curtis does such a commendable job as a damaged and grisled PTSD vitcim, preparing for 40 years for her nightmare to return.  It was so nice to see Nick Castle reprise his role as Michael, and his tall and lean frame exuding the haunting depth that really struck a nerve in me as a kid.  While a few sub-plots didn't work, and I wasn't necessarily "scared" by this movie, I felt like this was a chapter that needed to happen.  I was able to completely forget about all of the (lame) sequels and just focus on the here and now -- and to me, this makes this movie a success in my book.  I loved it.  Happy Halloween, Michael.

Halloween (2018) is exactly the sequel we deserved. Tense, suspenseful, emotional and raw. Green's take on this new time-line is a sequel many fans of this broken, bitch-slapped and battered franchise, will welcome with open arms, even with its few missteps. A great film about the effects of prolonged and untreated trauma. Without Curtis, the message wouldn't be as impactful but she sells it with every tear, scream and fight. The opening credits rewind a decaying pumpkin and with that segment alone, the franchise begins anew.

So much potential, so little payoff. The possibilities were endless but in the end, Michael Myers is no longer the mysterious, raging psychopath of John Carpenter's imagination 40 years ago. Instead he is now merely a vehicle to feature Jamie Lee Curtis as a modern-day crusty, kooky, grandmother hell-bent on revenge. The plodding plot completely lacks suspense and creativity and never develops into the edge of your seat horror flick that Carpenter delivered to audiences once upon a time. Not to mention (spoiler alert), Halloween (2018) is simply the latest in an endless string of weak Hollywood movies that can't seem to come up with an escape situation that doesn't include a prisoner transport bus. So tired. So cliche. Such lazy writing. In the end, "lazy" aptly describes Hollywood (2018). Fans of the original Halloween deserve much better. Too bad Michael Myers didn't slash this film until it ended on the editing room floor. That's where it deserved to be.

Blumhouse Productions wouldn't have much reason to exist if it weren't for horror film franchises, and more often than not their movies scrape the bottom of the barrel when it comes to delivering anything beyond a date night jump scare. So I have to hand it to them for resurrecting a film series that was pretty subpar from the first sequel on, flagrantly retconning its last nine films, then somehow delivering a fitting sequel to the seminal 1978 original. David Gordon Green's Halloween joins Mad Max: Fury Road and Blade Runner 2049 in the small but growing echelon of successful decades-late soft reboots, and from beginning to end I was grinning from ear to ear.

I decided on a lark a few hours before I attended the screening to reacquaint myself with John Carpenter's classic original in order to more properly gauge the fan service, and the new film has it in spades. From the OG title card font to some very clever scene parallels, the 40 year gap between films is bridged almost seamlessly, hindered only by the unfortunate absence of Donald Pleasence (since, y'know, he's been dead for 23 years). The pacing, dread, and gore of the original are all here but suitably amped up a bit for modern audiences, as even the frat bro sitting next to me was audibly disturbed by a few of the kill scenes. Plus, you can't really beat the iconic score that permeates the runtime, keeping the dark atmosphere amidst the more perfunctory and predictable passages.

What elevates the film past meeting the baseline expectations set out by the original is that the movie reminds us that slasher flicks can be a lot of fun. In terms of dialogue, the exposition is treated with the proper amount of import to maintain tonal balance. Sure it's ham, but it's closer to prosciutto than Lunchables meat. As for the extraneous character driven moments, they range from naturally conversational to straight up comedic, and I wish Jamie Lee Curtis had told me after I'd been inducted to NHS "Screw college, go to Mexico." Speaking of Jamie Lee, it's obvious that her break through lead role has led her to this labor of love, and she's joined by an equally committed cast. This could have been a disaster or another easy cash-grab, but Halloween won't disappoint for horror fans and general audiences alike.

I live and breathe horror. In fact, most of the killings don't take place on camera at all and the movie isnt actually scary as theres no gore, no tension and not even any good jump scares because all the scenes are so predictable. Second, there is very little character development (especially for Laurie's daughter and her family) and the acting is average at best. Toss in an M Night Shyamalan-esque plot twist with Michael Myers psychiatrist which makes very little sense and an ending sequence which is so absurd, campy (que the etching on the bottom of the rifle) and full of holes that half of the theatre that I was in actually started laughing. I mean, Laurie Strode literally becomes a character which combines Ripley from Alien, Macgyver and Sarah Connor. Wow. Just wow that was bad.

Now for the good parts of the movie. Michael Myers mask is really cool and the kid who was being babysat was absolutely hilarious (best part of the movie). That is all.

In the end, I'm not saying dont go watch this movie because I did and you probably will too, regardless. This is just a warning and confirmation that other people were also fooled by these high profile movie critics and that you're not the only one who feels this way about this awful movie.

John Carpenter's Halloween is my all-time favourite horror film. Always has been, always will be. I've generally enjoyed most of the sequels, but everything after Halloween H20 has been a dumpster fire. When I heard they told Rob Zombie to fu*k off I was ecstatic. When I heard they were doing a direct sequel to the original I was excited. When I heard John Carpenter and Jamie Lee Curtis were returning my expectations immediately became unrealistic. After months of anticipation, I saw the film twice opening weekend, and had completely different reactions each time. This review is a tale of two Halloweens.

The hype machine was building for a long time. Everything I'd seen and heard about the movie had me pumped...but when I actually saw it, I left the theatre disappointed. When I began to think about why, the answer was simple - I'd spent the entire time comparing it to the original. It wasn't paced the same, it wasn't edited the same, it didn't feel like a 1970s horror movie. I don't know why I expected this to be exactly like the original, but I did, and that was stupid. Needless to say when I saw it a second time and actually judged it on its own merits, rather than constantly comparing it, I completely changed my tune. The movie sure isn't perfect, but it's quickly become one of my favourites in the series.

There are two things that make Halloween work - it disregards all the sequels, and the Carpenter influence is felt for the first time in a long time. Let's just ignore all the ridiculous things that happened to Michael Myers in the subsequent films, and that stupid brother/sister twist introduced in Halloween 2 is finally gone! What this movie does with Laurie Strode is a far more satisfying continuation for the character than what we got in H20. Although the real surprise is the fact they actually made Michael Myers scary and interesting again. For the first time in forty years they've brought the mystery back to the character. Everyone has their theories about what makes Michael tick, but thankfully we're given no answers. Once you start to explain why (family, cults, abuse), you take away everything that made him scary in the first place. He's the boogeyman, plain and simple.

There really is a lot to love in Halloween. Jamie Lee Curtis pours her heart and soul into the movie, John Carpenter's score is pure synth gold, and director David Gordon Green done a fine job re-creating the small town atmosphere and suspense of the original. It's gory, but not Friday the 13th gory, the humour (mostly) works, and there are plenty of nods to past Halloweens that longtime fans will appreciate. The story works well, but at times feels a little bloated, and certain characters are sadly underdeveloped because of it. Although the only thing I truly disliked about the movie was a five minute chunk in the third act that's just downright stupid. Otherwise this is a solid entry that puts the franchise back on the right track.


After more than a decade of crappy sequels and remakes, Halloween 2018 truly is a treat for fans of the franchise. It's a wonderful blend of nostalgia and evolution that genuinely feels like a continuation of the original Halloween, and not a copy. It rightfully brings the series back to its roots, while also giving the audience something new. The performances are strong, the characters are likeable, it's atmospheric, funny, tense, and surprisingly well-written. I guess it's a good sign when my biggest complaint about the movie is why they couldn't just call it Halloween Returns.

I give the movie all five stars. It was well written, directed, and paced. The first act follows basic formula with Michael being locked up at Smith's Grove Sanitarium then by some extreme means escapes again to go on a rampage in Haddonfield, Illinois to relive the same night back in Halloween 1978. This is a movie for both old and new fans mostly for the older fans of the original. Continuity wise the movie is a direct sequel to the original ignoring all the sequels including Halloween 2 which some fans may or may not like, but for valid reasons may be for the best since it brings Michael back to his roots as the unpredictable evil force of nature that he is. The movie contains references to other films of the series true fans would appreciate mainly one nodding to the Silver Shamrock masks from Halloween 3 shown in one scene. Another aspect of the movie that was great was it's use of cinematography mostly around the parts of Michael stalking his prey giving you the fear of being watched capturing the tone of the original, but with more advanced camera equipment. (SPOILERS START) There's a few plot twists that seem far fetched like the evil psychologist (maybe a Halloween 6 reference), but works well for the film for the better when the plot is instantly thrown away by Michael when the evil doctor becomes one of his victims showing Michael is a force that can't be controlled. Another campy moment was two goofy cops talking about what they're eating for lunch, but I was under the impression they were a reference to the two goofy cops from 5 which still works well for the movie. After that's all out of the way we get to the climax where Laurie faces Michael one last time. Jamie Lee Curtis reprises her roll again as Laurie Strode from the original and does a magnificent performance that really draws you in. After 40 years Laurie Strode is ready for Michael arming herself with multiple fire arms living in a house with trap doors and secret passageways, but at the same time suffering from post traumatic stress and grief that drives a wedge between her and her family except her granddaughter. The final act focuses on Laurie's final standoff against Michael which is the most exciting and suspenseful part in the movie that draws you in from start to finish. (SPOILERS END)  Overall I thought it was the best film of the franchise and if you're a fan of the original this one is a must see.

A direct sequel to the original John Carpenter classic, so why isn't is called Halloween II? Because it would be confusing to have three Halloween II's? Ahh, so, three Halloween's it is, the original, a remake and a sequel to the original, it makes sense. So this one, is a remake of Halloween 4: The Return of Michael Myers, with Laurie Strode, still in the picture and Michael's niece playing a lesser role. Mixed with Halloween H20, when it deleted it's previous installments to bring back Laurie Strode. So this one deletes all previous installments including H20, and the remakes and takes place as if Michael was caught on Halloween night 40 years ago. As with Halloween 4, Michael is being transferred, shit happens he breaks free and goes after his family, but in this alternate universe Laurie didn't die in a car accident and left her daughter, in this, she goes full on Sarah Conner, and prepares, because she knew Michael would escape one day, raising her daughter John Conner style also in preparation, which neither John nor Laurie's daughter took seriously til crap when down!! And yep, Mikey makes his way back to Haddonfield in time for Halloween and of course the Halloween dance at the high school. Smith's Grove must have the internet for inmates. All leading to a showdown between Ellen and the Queen Alien, crap, I mean all leading to Laurie and a showdown with her bro... Any real fans of the series, and I mean those in between sequels, part 6 in particular, the Cult of Thorn, I'm pretty sure they're hinted at in this, not sure, just my thought... As a whole I liked it, i liked the different slices of the other films in the series. (Spot the Season of the Witch masks?) Will there be a Halloween 2. Of course there will be, they have literally run out of ideas in Hollywoo. Filmbufftim on FB.

OUR MIKEY BOY'S FINALLY COME HOME!!!!!!!

HALLOWEEN (2018)

4 decades after he came home the first time, & now we get a sequel that retcons everything! As far as we're concerned, everything past the end of the first film didn't happen! And IMHO, there's more good than bad because of it.

At one hour & 46 minuets, there's a solid beginning, middle, & payoff to this film's plot; with setup & development for most of the cast, ending with a......wait, don't wanna spoil things. A high point of my viewing was playing spot the reference, there were quite a few, but they weren't annoyingly in your face.

The cast was awesome! Jamie Lee Curtis still hasn't lost her touch! I believed her as someone who went through a trauma & then spent decades using prepping to cope with the resulting PTSD. The folks playing her family did well. Judy Greer really sells it as Laurie's daughter, a person robbed of their childhood, due to parental baggage. Andi Matichak as Laurie's granddaughter was a typical modern teenager, very believable. And I was surprised to find Toby Huss, or as I know him, ARTIE, THE STRONGEST MAN.....IN THE WORLD, playing Laurie's son-in-law; he sorta took a back seat, but he was entertaining when we saw him. The rest of the cast added their own subtle flavors & textures to this pumpkin pie of a film, making it all the sweeter. Michael has returned to his roots, he IS The Shape, able to use whatever's on hand, or just his two hands, to do what he does best! No reason, no method to the madness. He. Just. Kills. And that's what makes him so awesomely terrifying.

The effects were minimal, & all practical. We went to real locations, each one with their own atmosphere of dread. Despite knowing what was gonna happen, they were able to build a solid amount of tension without relying on too many cheep jump scares

The music was pure Halloween. They didn't use the main theme or the classic score too much or too little, it was juuust right.

Halloween (2018) was a Halloween sequel WORTHY of being a Halloween sequel! It made Michael Audrey Myers frightening again. And while we may have lost the continuity of the second film, this one really made up for how bad the post H5 films were! I just wish the guy who originally produced these films had lived to see this one. I'm giving it 4 pumpkins outta 5! Happy Halloween, I can't wait to see what comes next; 'cause you KNOW he ain't dead, as the best slashers never die!

You could wipe out at least 25% of this movie and it would be pretty good. I liked a lot of stuff, but first, the bad:

 There were a lot of pointless characters and silly, goofy humor to scoff at that cheapened and snuffed out all chance of scariness. There was a scene running through the woods that led nowhere and could've been deleted and no one would miss it. Everything relating to the podcast wasn't necessary. A conversation about sandwiches was distracting, mindnumbing and should have been cut. Corny lines like "Gotcha" and "Happy Halloween" didn't need to be added. The plot twist with the doctor was cheesy and a desperate attempt to give unnecessary explanation. These things dumbed down the movie that, for the first maybe half, was mostly going in the right direction. 

Also, there was little room for suspense. Michael Myers rushed to gory killings and did very little of the creepy stalking that made him such a nightmare creepy killer. His character was reduced to a cheap slasher in many instances. Also, he was shown without his mask way too much and it took away from The Shape.

So what did I like? The opening credits really made me want to watch the rest of the movie. Most of the music was really good until it seemed to get louder and more cheesy. Michael Myers did a pretty good job of moving like Michael Myers most of the time. The acting was surprisingly good all around. I was worried about Laurie Strode being too Rambo but it stayed tasteful. I liked it. Much like Sarah Conner.

To sum it up, the music and lights were toned down and the fat and fluff was edited out, along with the cheesiness and attempt at comedy, this would have made me pretty happy. More stalking and less gore would have made it scary and pretty awesome. Nice try.

From the early announcements of preproduction, this movie boasted itself a true tribute to John Carpenter's immortal classic, promising to be a reprisal to the original's masterful minimalism and intimacy, only to serve as it's modern day antithesis. The original, a slow-building masterpiece of suspense and dread, was modernized to a fast paced and overcomplicated extroversion in celebration of the original's 40th anniversary. Despite the hype, this film goes out of it's way to contradict everything special about it's source material in a fashion all too common in the genre today.

Of all it's offenses, it's worst is glaring: it simply wasn't scary. In wanting to exist outside of genre tropes, it sacrifices horror for it's prioritized drama, action and comedy. David Gordon Green does well to avoid clîched jump scares by avoiding scares all together, sometimes even having you laugh during a murder. Murder means nothing in this movie (a serious misstep for a slasher film), serving only as gratuitous action sequences to rack up a bodycount. Moments that could have been quite suspenseful are filled with soundtrack, dialogue, or quickness. The Michael we knew wasn't muscle slaughtering the lambs of an infinitely generating cast; he was a ghostly apparition who quietly preyed on three babysitters, watching from afar with such patience, only to get closer and closer, and when he could finally reach, he stung, not for the sake of murder, but to watch how they'd behave in his hands. He was a genuine-fucking-creep, and that nuanced eeriness is replaced with an obvious masculine mindlessness.

Meta references to the franchise and the film's self awareness may have worked well in Wes Craven's Scream (1996), but these postmodern gestures served no function in Halloween (2018) other than to patronize fans, featuring easter eggs that may have pleased Marvel audiences but does little to keep you present. In one monologue, a high school student references the original as being pale to numb desensitized modern audiences, and it's in this philosophy that the movie fails to deliver on it's promises. And it's wrong - the original film does hold up! Television screenings, film restorations, soundtrack pressings, horror conventions, merchandising, and theatrical screenings have proven audiences are not too far gone to enjoy the sophisticated suspense Carpenter brought to audiences in 1978.

To it's credit, the movie has some genuine moments that will make you swell up, brilliant humor, and witty dialogue, but these moments ultimately did not save it from it's excessive character development and extroverted killings.

It may be a surprise to say I rank this film amongst the lowest in the franchise, but it's for its missed opportunity and broken promises that I cannot support this attempt. With all of it's easter eggs to show the fans they truly understood the series, this movie mischaracterizes the original more than any film preceding.

We waited forty years - for this?
Best movie in the entire series.

A great sequel that gets rid of years of nasty baggage. Halloween does a great job of mixing small amounts of humor, large amounts of gore, and a fantastic cast. For starters, the humor is in small doses throughout the film, and creates a personality for the characters in it. Second, the gore isn't over the top, but creates a sense that Micahel is back and ready. Some deaths are nods to previous throughout the series, and others are new and creative. They create a good sense of horror and fear that Micahel has been waiting to feed his insatiable bloodlust. Lastly, the cast does a fantastic job. The cast portrays each character in typical Halloween fashion. Jamie Lee Curtis does amazing as allows and so do her counterparts. I tip my hat to the writers and directors of this film for such a great rollercoaster of horror, fear, suspense, and story. 

My only issue with the film is the story lacks a good 5-10 minutes of tying up loose ends. Please don't read farther if you do not want anything SPOILED. Michael was not shot in the first film so he is alive. Myers was captured by officer Dawkins rather than being shot 5-6 times in the torso. How he was captures, what happened during that process, and how they managed to keep him contained for so many years are all things I want answered. The last one question is a simple one but one sentence would've done that question justice. 

Otherwise, the film was amazing and different in the best way possible. It stuck to its roots and yet expanded it all in a short hour and forty minutes. The film does not drag at all and I would recommend it to old fans, horror buffs, or even newcomers to a bloody franchise.
This was a hell of a sequel

The shooting methods weren't quite as good as they were in the first, but the music, the new mask, and the character of Michael and Laurie that brings intensity and suspense has done nothing but amplify with time. One of the best thrillers I have seen in my life.

This new addition to the Halloween franchise is seemingly and updated take on 1998's H20, but is significantly better than that film in many regards. Laurie Strode's character arc in this film feels very natural and timely in a Me-Too era, and Jamie Lee Curtis knocks it out of the park with her performance. From a horror movie standpoint, the movie mostly excels when it comes to delivering the scares and expected blood and gore. There are some awkward plot elements and the story ends up going in an unexpected, but not necessarily amusing, direction toward the end of the second act. But the script corrects course for the finale which is exhilarating and action packed, and also very scary. Halloween 2018 represents the best of modern reboots and revivals of classic IP.

Walked into this film a little hesitant, but darn did I find this to be the best Halloween film since the original.

Although the constant Halloween continuity reboots have gotten a bit draining, having only the first film count and Michael no longer being Laurie's brother returns Michael back to this random, inexplicable force of death. None of the other films, including maybe even the original, have stressed so much the unease of not knowing what makes him tick.

The tight camerawork also may come closest to the original to Michael more of a menacing thing than man. The scares are kept pretty varied as the direction for Michael's appearances and kills shift seamlessly between subtle and in-your-face. In an age when slashers have become predictable, this movie manages to surprise at points in its ferocity.

The film looks good in general with the whole thing having this 70s look that manages to utilize darkness without sacrificing color. The opening sequence is a very effective and weird-little variation on the original into. The classic music theme is back. 

The script does a surprisingly good job of delving into the emotional and psychological aftermath of Michael's killings. There is a lot of setup and exposition before Michael escapes, but the dialogue is so smooth, it isn't an issue. There are actually a few funny lines spread throughout.

I really liked Jamie Lee Curtis' performance as Laurie Strode even more than her portrayal in H20, and she was already pretty good in that. Here she is a half-crazed, survivalist grandma suffering from PSTD. Curtis easily switches between tough and tormented. Credit should also be given to Andi Matichak as the granddaughter. She gives a good job of playing the new young heroine, and I kind of wished she had more screentime.

Only big knitpick is that the authorities use movie logic here, and there is some suspension of disbelief in how they handle things.

This was such a better movie than H20 and Resurrection that also starred Jamie Lee Curtis. It was definitely more scarier, darker and more suspenseful. It was done right and would watch this one again like the original classics. The only thing I will add, is that they should focus more on why Michael Myers is who he is. There should be more back story to why Michael Myers is evil and kills.

This newest "Halloween" film is actually the 11th film in the series.. of those I have seen 10 of them (skipping the sequel to Rob Zombie's travesty of a remake).. and this film (which erases all of the continuity after the original) is a fine follow up to John Carpenter's original film.  It captures the tone of Carpenter's film and Jamie Lee Curtis is quite good in her best role of the series.  The only thing that blemishes it is that a couple of characters kindof disappear without storyline resolution and the ending feels a bit rushed.. but other than that I quite liked the movie..

My expectations for this movie were huge...and I was not disappointed! Jamie Lee Curtis kicked some serious ass and proved that Laurie Strode is still a survivor.  The kills are gruesome, and Michael Myers comes back more brutal then ever. The visuals of the movie are also phenomenal.  Like the original, lighting and various long shots are used to create frightening atmosphere and suspense. Between the murder and mayhem,  there are some hilarious comedic moments...the best being between a young boy and his babysitter ??.  The absolute BEST part of the movie is the score. John Carpenter blew this out of the water by not just reworking the original music, but also creating some new pieces that really made Halloween such a terrifying treat. ????

While there were a few nice homage moments, overall I found myself thinking - this is nowhere near as good as the first, and the script seemed to be all over the place. This franchise would have been a great one to carry on the Debra Hill direction of including a heavy female influence. Her dialogue in the original really made the characters real and relatable. Ultimately, this film was disappointing, but I won't say it was all bad.

Not what I expected, but the message about how a woman was still affected by something that happened 40 years ago was conveyed well. And her coping mechanisms was a more reality thing of how people with abuse or past trauma deal with pain. But other then that, the movie sucked!

This movie was awful.  I am a huge MM/Halloween fan.  1978's was the absolute best and I've been hooked on the Myers style ever since.  Though there have a been a couple of others in this franchise that were kind of good, the majority were bad. This one is no exception.  While I very much appreciated the homage this movie paid to the 1978 released (and there were quite a few) in so many scenes, it wasn't enough to warrant a full star.  Next time, let me write the movie....please?
Best Halloween sequel to date.

A return to form for this franchise. A direct sequel to Halloween (1978) this film retcons all of the sequels (even kinda making fun of the absurdity of them during the film). The film takes place 40 years after the events of the first film. Michael Myers (Nick Castle) is being transferred from the mental institute he's been at for the last 40 years. Laurie Strode (Jamie Lee Curtis) is still around the town of Haddonfield, but has become a bit of a recluse and paranoid. Laurie isn't quite the "scream queen" she was back in 1978. She's been prepping herself for the return of Michael and learning everything she needs to know, so that she's basically never in a vulnerable position again. Because of all this she's become estranged from her daughter Karen (Judy Greer). Her granddaughter Allyson (Andi Matichak) stays in contact with her and is always trying to include her in their life still regardless of her moms wishes. Well if you've seen any horror film obviously something goes down and Michael is back on Halloween night seeking not just Laurie, but killing endlessly. The plot is pretty simple here and well it doesn't actually need to be complex for it to work. Michael is as creepy as ever. Not speaking a word with just his heavy breathing feeling in some scenes. The gore and kills are intense in this one. There's some extremely brutal and gory scenes in this one. It works well. I can't say much more. The characters work well here and if I had to gripe I would have liked to get a bit more of the back story between Laurie and Karen. We kind of just jump into what's going on, but it reveals itself nicely. I really enjoyed Will Patton as Officer Hawkins. I actually found him to be one of my more favorite characters since he always has a great on screen presence. Overall, a great horror film that continues the tradition of the first film. It has the perfect blend of horror, gore and story. I definitely recommend checking this one out!

Absolute junk. No point. Starts off well and then it goes straight to fast mode. Its all over the place. Not remotely scary. A disgrace to the original film. The damn Akkad family ruined this whole franchise.
Enjoyed it as much if not more than the original. Really good movie.

Halloween (2018), now the ONE true sequel to the 1978 film - written and directed by David Gordon Green, written in part by Danny McBride, and wow, I really enjoyed this film. This is an excellent horror film and a great sequel, scary as hell! David Gordon Green does a fantastic job creating suspenseful atmosphere here, as well as with the amazing, long tracking shots of Michael Myers as he stalks his next victim. With the use of silence in certain scenes, paired with the brutal kills, this is easily one of my favorite horror films this year, right next to A Quiet Place.
One thing this script does quite well is building upon the lore of The Shape and laying to rest some issues or questions you may have had with many of the previous sequels or remakes.

Seeing as how Danny McBride wrote part of this script, I feel it's safe to say some of the more grounded comedic moments in the film came from his hand. If you've ready any of my horror/thriller reviews, you'll know I am generally not a fan of the way comedy is sprinkled throughout; just look at how I felt about The Nun. With this film, I loved the comedic elements, where they were placed to add some humanity and a lighter air in those moments. But I know these moments will rub some others the wrong way, and that's perfectly fine. Of course the music from John Carpenter just puts you in the zone seeing this film on the big screen too. Jamie Lee Curtis as Laurie suffering from PTSD all those years, she knocks this role out of the park, as expected; she is THE scream queen. This time around she's calculating, manipulative, lethal - everything she brings adds that much to the story. And Nick Castle reprising his role as Michael Myers, just as menacing as ever!

So many people complaining about continuity; some didn't get the very obvious continuation of the first film, even though the film did a fine job of explaining where it stood in the overall saga, and others just don't appreciate a film that ignores the bad sequels. Like yeah, they had their moments, but in comparison to this, they look like trash.

This is a film for Halloween 1978 purists; it has the same DNA, random kills, simple plot, and mystery; it even poses the same questions as the original: Is Michael a man or a supernatural force? He's both.

The sibling plot was dropped, first introduced in Halloween 2, and this was perhaps the best decision they could ever make, because it made Michael scary again... Nobody is safe, and you don't have to be related to him to be his victim.

It was certainly the best film since probably Halloween 2, and I may even rank it higher now.

It isn't without its flaws, particularly the Dr. Sartain subplot, but this was clearly a nod to Halloween 6, and the Dr. Wynn character, also a clever metaphorical way of saying he wanted to be Michael, much like the obsessed fans of the real world. There were so many hidden messages, breaking the lines between fiction and reality, even the pumpkin intro at the start of the movie was basically saying 'Halloween is back', as a rotted old pumpkin reforms into the familiar trademark one from the original film.

For the first time, we see Michael scared, and the roles are reversed, Laurie becomes the stalker, and it works so well.

For a fan of the original, this was a dream come true, a modern version, a return for the classic characters, and everything was ramped up to the max.

I look forward to seeing more. Michael lives on, for a new generation to appreciate.

9.5/10

Time for my First Ever Movie Review, this one is Halloween (2018). First let me start by saying that if you haven't seen the original yet, WATCH IT!!! Before you see this one. With that out of the way I will say this, Best Movie of 2018, with out a doubt Jamie Lee Curtis in this movie is awesome, her role as Lori Strode is outstanding. The synopsis is as follows, a group of journalists go to interview Michael at the State Penetrenty he is staying in. When the journalist's leave and Michael is being transported to a new Prison the bus breaks down and Michael Escapes, from there he goes around town slashing people and trying to kill Lori. John Carpenter did a great job on this Soundtrack, the movie has many throwbacks to the original such as the amazing closet scene, as well as the Balcony Scene. Overall I would say David Green and the cast did an amazing job and I would recommend you no matter if you don't like slasher movies to go see this film. 4.5/5

Its a quality installment that uses many of the same techniques the first one did to help build suspense--and it does so effectively.  During a Halloween season that is severely lacking in competition, this is hands-down the horror flick to see.  While the film benefits from essentially wiping the slate clean from all the installments since the original, this also serves as a hindrance--at least to those who have followed the franchise up to this point.  There are numerous nods to the previous films but while some may see it as paying homage, others will be likely look at it as rehashing old material.  On the other hand, being the 11th incantation of the franchise, trying to be new and original is a monumentally difficult task as the Friday the 13th franchise has proven time and time again.  Still, despite its flaws, it stands a quality slasher that delivers everything you would want in a horror movie.  Like many horror films, many aspects of it fall apart under scrutiny, but those seeking to quench their bloodlust will be satisfied.
Absolutely loved it!!!
Loved it.  Same tone and feel as the original.  Glad they didn't incorporate the rest of the timeline.
started off interesting, but when the action starts, it's a bunch of nonsense.

I will occasionally see a horror movie in the theater but slasher movies are typically not something I pay to see.  In fact, I don't recall ever paying to see any of the Halloween, Friday the 13th, Nightmare on Elm Street, or Texas Chainsaw Massacre movies so this needed to happen.  Not only did I need to warp my reality even more but this movie seemed like it could be the end of an era, and after seeing it I think it really could be the end of an era.

The thing I like most about this is that every Halloween movie between the first one and this one can be thrown out and no one would even notice.  It connected perfectly with the first and only the first, and that was ironically also my biggest problem with this - continuity errors.  The best thing that I feel could happen from here is John Carpenter's original vision and plan for an anthology to happen rather than the old series about a mass serial killer.

Jamie Lee Curtis was good, convincing.  The whole movie was fairly plausible and could have stood on it's own without any prior knowledge of any of the other Halloween movies.  If any genre of movie can get away with heroine empowerment it's horror movies.  That brings me to another reason I decided to see this... 

... it really looks like Hollywood is completely forcing heterosexual white males out of the movie theaters.  I have three or four movies still on my radar for 2018 but they are all feminine led and I might skip out on all of them.  Most of 2019 doesn't look much better with straight white male alienation continuing.  So, if there is to be a last movie for me to see for awhile then it had to be this.

In the big picture against everything else this probably isn't a 7 of 10 movie but in what I consider a down year for movies there was nothing wrong enough for me to try and finagle it down to a 6 of 10.

When I saw the original Halloween, I was amazed by the chase sequence with how intense it was, even from a movie in 1978. The movie that started a whole series of slasher films. There was a down though. When I watched the original, it was really good, but not a timeless movie. Some parts got really repetitive and emotionless to the modern generation, but was definitely freaked out in the night-time sequence. Now when I watch this BETTER sequel, it was exactly what I had expected as a true fan who totally agrees with these film makers. It had better pacing and immediately got to the point and was emotional and intense the whole time. Heck with the jumpscare factors that plagued many 2010 movies. This film rocked it to where you would actually care about the characters. Even the soundtrack in my opinion was really well written and played by John. Will definitely buy on DVD and watch from time to time. This is the best and I mean the best slasher movie in 40 years. I hope many other films are inspired by this one and don't start off the cheesy franchises all over again.
